How to Represent Non-Representable Functors


Paolo Perrone

University of Oxford

2024

Abstract


The arrows of a category are elements of particular sets, the hom-sets. These sets are functorial, and their functoriality specifies how to compose the arrows with other arrows of the same category. In particular, it allows to form diagrams, making many abstract concepts graphically visible.

Presheaves and set-valued functors, in general, are not representable, and so their elements are not arrows in the usual sense. They can however still be seen as "arrow-like structures", which can be post-composed but not pre-composed (for the case of set functors), or pre-composed but not post-composed (for the case of presheaves). Therefore, we can still represent their structure graphically.

In this exposition we show how to draw and interpret these generalized diagrams, and how to use them to prove theorems. We will then study in detail, and represent graphically, a few concepts of category theory which are often considered hard to visualize: representability, weighted limits and colimits, and Cauchy completion (for unenriched categories).

We also sketch how to interpret the more general case of profunctors, and the Day convolution of presheaves.

1 Introduction


One of the most useful features of category theory and related fields is diagrams, and the technique of diagram chasing. Diagrams are a way to make abstract relations graphically evident, and to employ our visual or spatial skills to aid our reasoning.

The main idea behind diagrams is to compose things of a certain class to create more complex things of the same class. Many structures in mathematics are instances of this pattern, for example groups, monoids, and categories. Diagrams for these structures, and for their refinements, such as monoidal categories, arise naturally from this idea.

X→fY→gZ

However, these are not the only type of structure that we use in abstract mathematics. Of at least equal importance we have the more general idea of things of type A which act on things of type B to give us new things of type B . Group representations,monoid actions and modules are instances of this pattern. One may then wonder, can we draw these as well?

The good news is that we can. However, diagrams for this type of structures are less known and less established. Because of that, while they are useful, they tend to be less accessible to newcomers. This exposition aims at bridging this gap, with two canonical examples of such structures: set-valued functors (which we will simply call set functors) and presheaves.

The main idea is that we can represent graphically any functorial action on sets, and not just the ones given by categorical composition.

For example,given a functor F:C→ Set,we have sets FX which depend functorially on an object X . This is similar to what happens with the hom-functor,with entries C(A,X) ,but this time we have a single argument, X . In a certain sense,the functorial action of F is similar to the one of C(A,−):C→ Set,in its second variable. This suggests to interpret the elements f∈FX as of being like arrows, but which can only be post-composed, not pre-composed. A possible way to draw them is then as arrows to the object X ,coming from a "virtual object" which is not part of the category:

-→fX

The functorial action on a morphism g:X→Y can then be represented as follows:

∙⋯→X↦∙→fX→gY

Presheaves can be represented similarly, and dually.


While this idea is simple, and while it is a straightforward generalization of usual categorical composition, it seems to be less standard both in the literature and in introductions. A reason could be that for many basic concepts of category theory, the usual diagrams are enough. There are however concepts, such as weighted limits and Cauchy completion, which do benefit from these more general diagrams. Indeed, these structures are rather hard to "draw" otherwise, and probably because of that, they are often considered much harder to understand than, for example, ordinary limits. Still, they are quite important, especially as stepping stones towards their generalization to the enriched context.

In this exposition we will address precisely these two concepts, weighted limits and Cauchy completion. We will first establish our more general diagrammatic formalism (Section 2) and start by representing universal properties. We will then define and study weighted limits and colimits (Section 3), and turn to Cauchy completions in their many forms (Section 4). Finally, at the end, we will give some intuition on how to use this technique in more advanced situations, such as with profunctors, and with the Day convolution (Section 5).

Where these ideas have appeared before. The idea of set functors and presheaves as arrows from and to "extra objects" has always been present in the category theory folklore at least since Grothendieck, and has had a strong influence on higher category theory, see for example [Lur09] and the nLab page on motivation for sheaves,cohomology and higher stacks. 1

The first recorded use of diagram chasing with these ideas seems to be [Par70], see Section 2.2 therein (where what here we call "virtual arrows" are depicted as normal arrows). The first explicit, systematic use of these techniques in applications seems to be Leinster's work on self-similarity [Lei04a,Lei04b,Lei07,Lei11] (where "virtual arrows" are written with the symbol → ). The most recent one seems to be Di Liberti and Rogers' work [DLR24] (where "virtual arrows" are depicted as crossing a dotted line).

A deep analysis of these ideas and their pervasive, yet elusive presence in the category theory literature can be found in Ellerman's writings [Ell06,Ell07,Ell15] (where "virtual arrows" are called "chimera morphisms" or "heteromorphisms" -see Section 5.1 - and are sometimes written with the symbol ⇒) .

Finally, I learned from personal communication that in a few category theory courses taught around the world, for example in Cambridge and in Tallinn, this point of view is sometimes used, at least informally, to describe concepts such as representability and adjunctions.

Prerequisites. The material presented here should be accessible to anyone with a background in basic category theory, as contained for example in [Lei14], [Rie16], or [Per24]. Knowledge of some enriched category theory may give an additional perspective, but it is not required.

Acknowledgements. I learned many of the ideas presented here through fruitful discussions with Bartosz Milewski, David Jaz Myers, Mario Román, Walter Tholen, and with the ItaCa collective, in particular Ivan Di Liberti and Fosco Loregian.

I also want to thank Nathanael Arkor, John Baez, David Corfield, Tom Leinster, Morgan Rogers, and Mike Shulman, for pointing out literature sources where these ideas are used.

This work was developed to provide infrastructure for my work on probability, funded at the time of writing by Sam Staton's ERC grant "BLaSt - A Better Language for Statistics".



1 https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/motivation+for+sheaves%2C+cohomology+and+higher+stacks




2 Diagrams for set functors and presheaves


Throughout this paper,let C be a locally small category.

Consider a set functor on C ,i.e. a functor F:C→ Set. On objects,it maps an object A of C to a set,which we denote FA . On morphisms,it maps a morphism g:A→B to a function FA→FB which we denote as follows.

FA→g∗FB

f↦g∗f

Particular set functors are the representable ones. Those are functors C→ Set in the form (up to natural isomorphism)

C(R,A)→g∘−C(R,B)

(R→fA)↦(R→fA→gB)

for some object R of C .

Similarly,and dually,consider a presheaf P:Cop → Set. On objects,it again maps A to a set PA . On morphisms,it maps g:A→B to a function in the opposite direction, g∗:PB→PA , which we denote as follows.

PB→g∗PA

p↦g∗f

Particular presheaves are the representable ones. Those are presheaves Cop→Set in the form (up to natural isomorphism)

C(B,R)→−∘gC(A,R)

(B→pR)↦(A→gB→pB)

for some object R of C .

In other words:

  • In general, set functors and presheaves map objects to generic sets, and morphisms to generic functions (in a functorial way).

  • Representable set functors and presheaves map objects to sets of arrows of C ,and morphisms to the operations of pre- and postcomposition of these arrows.

The main idea that we want to present here is to interpret all set functors and presheaves in terms of "arrows", but of a more general kind.

2.1 Virtual objects and virtual arrows


Let R be an object of C ,and consider the representable functor C(R,−):C→ Set. We can visualize its action as a cone-like diagram over C in the following way.


  • On objects,it assigns to an object A to the set of all arrows R→A :




(Here we draw sets of two or three arrows, but these sets could also be empty, or infinite, etc.)

  • On morphisms,it assigns to an arrow g:A→B the postcomposition function:




(Not every arrow R→B may be in the form g∘f for some f:R→A . In the diagram above, and in the examples that follow,we assume that the unlabeled middle arrow R→B is not of this form.)

The postcomposition function, equivalently, is a way of telling us which triangles in the diagram below commute:




For example,the triangle formed by f,g and g∘f commutes. (The unlabeled arrow does not make any triangle with g commute.)

In general there may be several arrows A→B . So there are many possible triangles as follows, and the functor C(R,−):C→ Set tells us which ones are commutative.




(For example, in the diagram above, there are four commutative triangles.)

So we can view the representable functor C(R,−):C→ Set as forming a large conical diagram where the base of the cone is the entire category C ,the vertex of the cone is the object R ,and sets of arrows connect the vertex to the objects at the base. Note that:


  • In a traditional cone, one usually wants a single arrow from the tip to each point of the base. Our conical diagram is more general, there is an entire set instead (possibly infinite, possibly empty);

  • In a traditional cone, one usually wants all triangles to commute. Here instead the rules for which triangles commute are specified by the functor (or equivalently, by composition of arrows in C );

  • The object R appears both at the vertex and at the base,and the identity is one of the connecting arrows.

Similarly,and dually,consider a representable presheaf C(−,R):Cop → Set.




We can view it as forming an upside-down conical shape ("co-conical") as follows.




Once again, the action on morphisms (precomposition) specifies which triangles commute.

Let's now introduce the main idea of this work: we can interpret non-representable set functors as forming cones like the ones above, but where the tip is not an object of our category. We will call it a virtual object. 2 More precisely,let F:C→ Set be any set functor. For every object A , FA is a set. We draw the elements of the set FA as dashed arrows as follows,




and call them virtual arrows from the virtual object ∙ to A . (When one is considering many functors at once, one may want to distinguish the virtual point of each functor by labeling it for example as ∙F . See also Section 2.3.)



2 This is not related to virtual double categories as far as I know. Since I’m not using any double categories here, this terminology should not cause any confusion.




On morphisms, F assigns to an arrow g:A→B a function as follows:




We can view it as a rule to post-compose a virtual arrow into A with g ,and obtain a virtual arrow into B :




In other words,the virtual arrows are things that we can postcompose (with arrows of C ),but not precompose. Just as for representable functors,the action of F on morphism tells us which triangles in the following diagram commute:




In summary, can view a set functor as forming a large conical diagram, which we call virtual cone, where the base of the cone is the entire category C ,the vertex of the cone is the virtual object ∙ , and sets of virtual arrows connect the vertex to the objects at the base:




The functor action on morphisms tells us which triangles in the cone commute. Note moreover that by functoriality of F ,

  • For all A and f∈FA,(idA)∗f=f ,meaning that identities indeed behaves like (left) identities on virtual arrows;

  • For all g:A→B,g:B→C and f∈FA,(g′∘g)∗f=g∗′(g∗f) ,meaning that the composition between real and virtual arrows is associative.

In other words, virtual arrows behave "as much as possible like actual arrows of a category". Possible interpretations are:


  • The virtual object `"behaves like an object of C ,but we don’t have access to it,we can only see its image projected onto the other objects"`.

  • The virtual object is `"an object we would like to add to C from the left,or from above,or from the in-direction, without breaking the category structure"`.

  • The virtual object,together with its arrows,is an `"entry point to C "`,or `"a consistent way to arrive into some object of C from elsewhere"`.

Consistent means,for example,that we can enter A using the virtual arrow f and then move to B using the real arrow g ,or we can equivalently enter B directly,using the virtual arrow g∗f ,and these two ways are equivalent.

In order to make rigorous arguments about virtual arrows, it is helpful, in what follows, to promote ∙ to an actual object of a category,an extension of C . To do so,we have to add its identity map (the functor F does not specify any arrows into ∙ ). So let’s define the following category.

Definition 2.1. Let C be a category,and let F:C→ Set be a functor. The category C+F has

  • As objects,the ones of C plus an extra object E ;

  • As morphisms between the objects coming from C ,the ones of C ;

  • As morphisms E→A ,where A is an object of C ,the elements of FA (`"virtual arrows"`);

  • The identity of E as the unique morphism with codomain E .

The composition of morphisms of C is as in C ,and between morphisms E→A and A→B is as specified by functoriality of F .

In C+F ,all arrows are real arrows,of course. But it is still helpful to keep track of which arrows come from C and which from F . Therefore we will draw morphisms out of E still as dashed,and refer to them still as "virtual arrows".

Let's now turn to presheaves. We can represent them similarly, and dually, as virtual co-cones, where the virtual arrows now point to a virtual object:




This time,the virtual arrows are things that we can precompose (with arrows of C ),but not postcompose. Possible interpretations are:

  • The virtual object `"behaves like an object of C ,but we don’t have access to it,we can only probe it by mapping the other objects into it"`.


  • The virtual object is `"an object we would like to add to C from the right,or from below,or from the out-direction, without breaking the category structure"`.

  • The virtual object,together with its arrows,is an `"exit point of C "`,or `"a consistent way to leave the objects of C and go elsewhere"`.

Again,consistent means for example that we could leave A equivalently by using the virtual arrow g∗p ,or by moving from A to B using the (real) arrow g and then leaving B using p .

Note that the idea that "set functors are things that go into our objects" and "presheaves are things that go out of our objects" is implicitly used very often in category theory:

Example 2.2. Let F: Top → Set the functor mapping a topological space to the set of its path-connected components. (Readers less familiar with topology may want to think of graphs, or even categories, instead.) This functor is not representable. It is however quite similar to other representable functors Top → Set which "probe our spaces using particular shapes",such as points, open curves,or loops. (These functors are represented by the one-point space,by R ,and by the circle S1 respectively.) Indeed, F can be seen as entering a space A ,and instead of "looking" for points or curves,it "looks" for entire path components of A ,no matter their shape. No actual space exists that has such a general,shifting shape,and so we can view elements of FA only as virtual arrows into A . (While no such object exists,using virtual arrows we can preserve the "going into A " flavor of this functor.)

Example 2.3. Suppose that the category C does not have all products. Given objects X and Y , the presheaf P=C(−,X)×C(−,Y) may fail to be representable. Now given an object A ,the virtual arrows out of A ,i.e. the elements of PA=C(A,X)×C(A,Y) are pairs of (real) arrows out of A ,namely A→X and A→Y :




Of course,pairs of arrows are not (single) arrows,and if the product X×Y does not exist,these pairs don't even correspond to single arrows in a natural way. But still, each one of these pairs is a thing that goes out of A . The elements of PA ,for each A ,(and for each presheaf P ),still have a sense of "leaving A ". In this sense it is useful to see elements of non-representable presheaves as things that go out, as if they were (single) arrows, but potentially more general. (This example is particularly nice, in general not every presheaf has tuples of real arrows as elements. But the interpretation of "things that go out" can still be used in general.)

Example 2.4. Suppose that the category C does not have all equalizers. Given parallel arrows g,h:X→Y ,the presheaf P=C(−,X)×C(−,Y)

A↦PA={f:A→X:g∘f=h∘f}⊆C(A,X)

may fail to be representable. In this case,one could see the virtual arrows f∈PA as some real arrows A→X ,since PA is a subset of C(A,X) . The "virtual" part is however that these are not all arrows A→X . That is,there is no object, X or any other,such that the arrows A→X are exactly the elements of PA .

Definition 2.5. Let C be a category,and let P:Cop → Set be a presheaf. The category C+P has


  • As objects,the ones of C plus an extra object E ;

  • As morphisms between the objects coming from C ,the ones of C ;

  • As morphisms A→E ,where A is an object of C ,the elements of PA (`"virtual arrows"`);

  • The identity of E as the unique morphism with domain E .

The composition of morphisms of C is as in C ,and between morphisms A→B and B→E is as specified by functoriality of P .

This idea of virtual cones and co-cones is quite simple, but as we will see, it can help our intuition with several advanced category theory concepts.

2.2 Representable functors and universal properties


The first categorical concept that we analyze using our point of view on set functors and presheaves is representability. We use the definition of representable functor given for example in [Rie16, Chapter 2], which we recall:

Definition 2.6. A set functor F:C→ Set is called representable if there exists a natural isomorphism ϕ:F→≅C(R,−) for some object R of C .

Similarly,a presheaf P:Cop → Set is called representable if there exists a natural isomorphism ϕ:P→≅C(−,R) for some object R of C .

In either case we call R the representing object,and ϕ its universal property.

We can redefine representability using our virtual arrows: a functor is representable if and only if its virtual object and arrows correspond to some real objects and arrows, inside our category. More precisely:

Theorem 2.7. A functor F:C→ Set is represented by an object R if and only if the inclusion functor I:C↪C+F admits a retraction functor Π:C+F→C mapping C⊆C+F to itself and E to R ,and satisfying any of the following equivalent conditions:

(i) Π (and not just I ) is fully faithful,meaning that for every A of C,Π maps each "virtual arrow" E→A bijectively to a "real arrow" R→A ;



(Sometimes, as in the diagram above, we will write the resulting "real arrows" still as dashed. See Remark 2.9.)



(ii) Π is left-adjoint to the inclusion I (i.e. it is a reflector).

(The categories C+F and C+P are defined in Definitions 2.1 and 2.5.)

Corollary 2.8. Dually,a presheaf P:Cop → Set is representable if and only if the inclusion functor C↪C+P admits a retraction which is either fully faithful,or equivalently,right-adjoint (a co-reflector).

As we will see in the proof, we don't just have an equivalence of properties (there exists a bijection, etc.), but even of structures (the bijections themselves correspond).

Proof. First let’s prove the equivalence with condition (i). Note that,since any retraction Π must restrict to the identity on C⊆C+F ,we only need to specify its action on E and on the arrows with domain E (i.e. the "virtual object and arrows").

First suppose that F is represented by R . Then each object A of C there an isomorphism ϕA:FA→≅C(R,A) (natural in A ). Recall that the hom-set C+F(E,A) is defined to be exactly the set FA ,so equivalently we have an isomorphism ϕA:C+F(E,A)→C(R,A) . Define now Π(E):=R and Π(idE):=idR ,and for every f:E→A,Π(f):=ϕA(f) . (On the subcategory C , we take Π to be the identity.) This is functorial: for every f:E→A and g:A→B ,we have that

Π(g∘f)=ϕB(g∗f)=g∘ϕA(f)=Π(g)∘Π(f),

where in the second equality we used naturality of ϕ ,i.e. commutativity of the following diagram:




By construction Π is a retract of the inclusion C↪C+P . Moreover,since ϕA is a bijection, we have that the mapping Π gives a bijection between "virtual arrows" E→A and "real arrows" R→A .

Conversely,suppose that Π:C+F→C is fully faithful. Again,on C it must necessarily be the identity. The action of Π on arrows gives an assignment

C+F(E,A)=FA→ϕAC(R,A)

f↦Π(f)

which is natural in A by functoriality: for every g:A→B ,

ϕ(g∘f)=Π(g∘f)=Π(g)∘Π(f)=g∘Π(f).

Moreover,this mapping ϕA is a bijection by hypothesis. Therefore we have a natural isomorphism ϕ:F→C(R,−) .

For the equivalence of (i) and (ii),notice that any retraction Π:C+F→C gives a bijection

(2.1)C(Π(E),A)=C(R,A)↔≅C+F(E,A)=C+(E,I(A))

Π(f)←f


natural in A ,as above,if and only if it is left-adjoint to the inclusion I . The latter means that we have bijections

C(Π(X),A)→≅C+F(X,I(A))

ϵA∘Π(f)=Π(f)↔f

for all objects A of C and X of C+ ,natural in X and A . (Here we can take the counit ϵ of the adjunction to be the identity,since Π is a retraction.) The case X=E is exactly (2.1),and for X∈C,Π acts as the identity,

C(Π(X),A)=C(X,A)↔ id C(X,A)=C+F(X,I(A))

Π(f)=f←f

naturally in A . For naturality in X ,consider a morphism h:X→Y of C+F ,and the naturality diagram as follows.

C(Π(Y),A)↔≅C+F(Y,I(A))

−∘Π(h)↓−∘h

C(Π(X),A)↔≅C+F(X,I(A))

We have a few cases:

  • If X,Y∈C ,the square commutes since Π(g)=g and the horizontal arrows are identities;

  • If X=E ,and Y∈C ,the diagram reduces to the following,

C(Y,A)↔≅C+F(Y,A)

−∘Π(h)↓−∘h

C(R,A)↔≅C+F(E,A)

which commutes by functoriality of Π ;

  • For the identity E→E ,the condition is trivial;

  • There are no morphisms A→E for A∈C .

To summarize, representable set functors and presheaves are those for which "virtual arrows are not-so-virtual". In general, the virtual arrows of functors (or presheaves) can serve as "blueprint" for how actual arrows to (or from) a representing object, if it exists, look like.

Remark 2.9. Usually, in category theory, those "not-so-virtual arrows" are represented as dashed or dotted arrows. For example,suppose that the product X×Y exists. Then by definition,for every object A and every pair of arrows A→X and A→Y there exists a unique arrow A→X×Y making the following diagram commute: Let's now see why the dashed arrow above is exactly the "not-so-virtual arrow" in the sense of Theorem 2.7. The product X×Y is a representing object of the presheaf P=C(−,X)×C(−,Y) . As we saw in Example 2.3,the elements of PA ,i.e. the virtual arrows,are exactly pairs of real arrows A→X and A→Y . The universal property of the product says exactly that to each such pair there exists a (real,single) arrow A→X×Y . In the terminology of Theorem 2.7,this arrow A→X×Y (or A→R ) is the one obtained by the functor Π:C+F→C .





Now,in our formalism,these "not-so-virtual arrows" are real arrows of C ,not virtual,and so, technically, we should depict them as solid arrows, not dashed. However, they are exactly the real representatives of virtual arrows (in the sense of Theorem 2.7), and so, writing them as dashed, while technically an abuse of notation, is not too far a stretch. Somewhat conversely, one can see our dashed, virtual arrows as a generalization of those dashed arrows which appear in universal property diagrams. (Generalization to the case where no object actually satisfies the universal property.)

2.3 Natural transformations and the Yoneda embedding


Virtual arrows also allow us to visualize natural transformations between set functors or presheaves. Let's see how, starting with presheaves this time.

Consider two presheaves P,Q:Cop → Set. A natural transformation α:P⇒Q amounts to functions αA:PA→QA for all objects A ,and natural in A . We can view a natural transformation α as a virtual arrow between virtual objects. First of all,we draw now two virtual objects ∙P and ∙Q:




Now we can view α as an arrow between ∙P and ∙Q :




Now,the assignment αA:PA→QA should be a mapping from virtual arrows A→∙P to virtual arrows A→∙Q . It can be seen as a "virtual" postcomposition with α . That is,the map αA tells us that the following triangle commutes:


PA→αAQA

p′↦αA(p′)




Moreover,naturality in A says that this "virtual composition" is associative,




i.e. that the following tetrahedron commutes:




(One could even form a category with two extra objects analogous to C+P .)

Let’s now turn to set functors. Given F,G:C→ Set,we can similarly view a natural transformation as an arrow between virtual points, but crucially, in the opposite direction. Let's see how. First of all,a natural transformation α:F⇒G amounts to functions αA:FA→GA for all objects A . This would have to map virtual arrows ∙F→A to virtual arrows ∙G→→A . We see immediately that composition with a virtual arrow ∙F→∙G would not work:




Instead,we visualize a natural transformation α:F⇒G as precomposition with a virtual arrow ∙G→−→∙F :




In other words, it's a way to say that the following triangle commutes: Just as for the case of presheaves,naturality in A says that this composition is associative,i.e. that the tetrahedron above commutes.


FA→αAGA

f↦αA(f)




Let's now look at these natural transformations from a larger perspective. The second-most famous result of category theory is the Yoneda embedding theorem, which says that the embedding of a category C into its category of presheaves




is full and faithful. Replacing C by its opposite,we get the embedding on the left below,and taking opposites, we get the one on the right:

Cop →[C,Set]

C→[C,Set]op 

A↦C(A,−)

A↦C(A,−)

g→g∗=(−∘g)op 

B↦C(B,−)

B↦C(B,−)

Both are again fully faithful. Whenever this does not lead to confusion, we will denote the embedding C→[C,Set]op  again by Yon,and refer to it again as the Yoneda embedding.

(Keep in mind that,even if C is locally small,the categories [Cop ,Set] and [C,Set]op  may fail to be locally small.)

We can view these embeddings as ways to add "all virtual objects at once" to C ,in a certain sense,but let’s proceed with a little care. First of all,instead of adding new objects to C ,we are rather embedding C into a larger category. So we switch our notation as follows. Let’s do this for presheaves first:




All our virtual arrows have now been promoted as actual arrows of our category. (We will sometimes still write them as dashed.) Now the firstmost famous result of category theory, the Yoneda lemma, says that we have a natural bijection as follows.

PA→≅[Cop,Set](Yon(A),P)

In other words to each virtual arrow A→∙P there corresponds a unique real arrow Yon(A)→P in [Cop,Set] ,as the diagram above suggests. Since the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful,moreover, we know that to each arrow g:A→B there corresponds a unique arrow Yon(A)→Yon(B) ,the solid one in the diagram. However,in [Cop,Set] there may be arrows P→Yon(A) that we did not have before. So the picture may look more like the following one:





For functors, the situation is similar, but we have to keep in mind that the natural transformations are now reversed. Equivalently,we are embedding C into [C,Set]op  ,not [C,Set] . The Yoneda lemma now reads as follows:

(2.2)FA→≅[C,Set](Yon(A),F)=[C,Set]op(F,Yon(A)).

In other words,to each virtual arrow ∙F→A there corresponds a unique real arrow F→Yon(A) . However,as for presheaves,there may be extra arrows Yon(A)→F that we did not have before.





3 Weighted limits and colimits


Our graphical representation of set functors and presheaves can be used to give an intuitive interpretation of weighted limits and colimits.

In what follows,we will call a diagram in C a functor D:J→C from some small category J , which we can see as "indexing" the diagram.

Weighted limits and colimits are defined as follows.

Definition 3.1. Let D:J→C be a diagram,and let W:J→ Set be a set functor. A weighted limit of D with weighting W ,or W -weighted limit of D ,which we denote by

limJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,DJ⟩

is an object representing the following presheaf.

(3.1)Cop → Set 

A↦[J,Set](W−,C(A,D−))


(Note that this is a presheaf on C ,while W is a set functor on J .)

Dually,let D:J→C be a diagram,and let W:Jop → Set be a presheaf. A weighted colimit of D with weighting W ,or W -weighted colimit of D ,which we denote by

colimJ∈J⟨WJ,DJ⟩

is an object representing the following set functor.

(3.2)C→Set

A↦[Jop,Set](W−,C(D−,A))

(Note that this is a set functor on C ,while W is a presheaf on J .)

Weighted limits and colimits are alternative called indexed limits and colimits.

At first, this definition may not seem particularly suggestive. Let's now interpret this graphically, by means of our virtual arrows.

Remark 3.2. Sometimes one may be interested more generally in situations where the indexing category J is not small. In that case,a necessary condition for the (large-set-valued) presheaf (3.1) to be representable,is that for each A the set [J,Set](W−,C(A,D−)) is small. Indeed,that set needs to have the same cardinality as the hom-set C(R,A) ,where R is a representing object. The same is true for the functor (3.2).

3.1 Weighted cones and cocones


Consider a diagram D:J→C . A (usual) limit of D ,if it exists,is first of all a cone over D :




That is,an object T of C (the "tip" of the cone) together with an arrow cJ:T→DJ for each object J of J ,such that for every arrow g:J→K of D,Dg∘cJ=cK . In other words,each side triangle of the cone (involving T ) commutes:





A cone(T,c)is now a limit if it is a universal or terminal cone,meaning that for every cone (T′,c′) over D ,there exists a unique arrow between the tips u:T′→T such that for each J of J , cJ∘u=cJ′ ,i.e. the following triangle commutes:




Similarly, a colimit is a universal (initial) co-cone.

We can interpret a cone over a diagram as a way to extend our diagram by adding an object, the tip T ,and arrows from T to the nodes of the diagram,forming commutative triangles. A limit is then a universal way of doing so. The interpretation of weighted limits, and more generally of what we call weighted cones, is very similar, except that there may be an entire set of arrows (or better said,an indexed tuple) between T and the nodes of the diagram:




We can view this as a more general way of extending a diagram,by adding an extra object T and arrows from T to the diagram: having single arrows as sides of the cone is just a special case. We might now wonder:

  • How do we specify each tuple of arrows?

  • How do we know which triangles commute?

The answer to both, which might come expected after reading Section 2.1, is that we can use a functor W:J→ Set. We call this a weighting for the diagram. We can see the weighting functor as a "blueprint" for how we want these generalized cones to look: in mind:




Before we make this idea precise, in order to have the right intuition, it's worth keeping a few things


  • Recall that a set functor comes with a rule for which `"virtual triangles"` commute. For example, in the picture above, W may specify that one of the two arrows ∙⇢L (but perhaps not the other one) is the composition of one of the arrows ∙→J with J→L . We want the resulting cone in C to respect these commutativity relations. More things may commute in C ,but crucially,not fewer.

  • A way to rephrase the point above is that in a traditional diagram, two arrows may happen to be equal in C even if they are written with different symbols in the diagram,that is,if they are indexed by different arrows of J (the functor J is not always faithful). The same is true for these cones: different virtual arrows may be mapped to equal arrows in C (but equal virtual arrows cannot be mapped to different arrows).

  • Similarly,in a traditional diagram,given any two objects DJ and DK ,there may be more arrows DJ→DK of C than the ones appearing in the diagram,i.e. coming from J (the functor D is not always full). The same is true for these cones: there may be arrows T→DK in C which are not considered in the weighted diagram.

With this intuition in mind, let's give the precise definition.

Definition 3.3. Let D:J→C be a diagram and W:J→ Set be a set functor. A weighted cone over D (weighted by W ),or W -weighted cone,is an extension 3 of D to a functor D+:J+W→C , agreeing with D on J . We call D+E the tip of the cone.




Dually,let W:Jop → Set be a presheaf. A weighted co-cone over D (weighted by W ),or W -weighted co-cone,is an extension of D to a functor D+:J+W→C . We call D+(E) the tip of the co-cone.



3 Here we mean an extension in the common sense of the word,not a Kan extension. (See however Section 3.5.)




(Once again,the categories C+F and C+P are defined in Definitions 2.1 and 2.5.) Equivalently,cones and cocones over D are commutative diagrams of functors as follows.(3.3)




(These diagrams may remind the reader of Kan extensions. That is a correct intuition, see Section 3.5.)

The main result of this section is now that weighted limit and colimits are exactly universal weighted cones.

Theorem 3.4. Let D:J→C be a diagram,and let W:D→ Set be a weighting for D . A W -weighted limit of D is,equivalently,a weighted cone D+:D+W→D (with tip T ) which is terminal: given any W -weighted cone D+′ (with tip T′ ),there is a unique morphism u:T′→T such that for all J of J and w∈WJ we have that D+w∘u=D+w ,i.e. the following triangle commutes.




Dually,given a presheaf W:Jop → Set,a W -weighted colimit of D with weighting W is equivalently an initial weighted co-cone.

Note that the terminality condition must be checked for each of the arrows T→DJ separately, in case there are more than one.

Let's now prove this theorem. The main argument, contained in the next two lemmas, connects weighted cones and cocones with the presheaves appearing in Definition 3.1.

Lemma 3.5. Let D:J→C be a diagram with weighting W:D→ Set. A W -weighted cone over D with tip T is equivalently given by a collection of maps

WJ→ϕJC(T,DJ)

natural in J .

Dually,given a presheaf W:Dop → Set,a W -weighted co-cone with tip T is equivalently given by a collection of maps

WJ→ϕJC(DJ,T)

natural in J .


The proof is a generalization of the argument in the proof of Theorem 2.7.

Proof. We will prove the case of functors, the case of presheaves is completely analogous and dual. First,let D+:J+W→C be a weighted cone. Its action on morphisms,in particular on the "virtual arrows" E→J ,induces the following mapping for every J∈J :

J+W(E,J)→C(D+E,D+J)

w↦D+w.

Recall now that by definition,the set J+W(E,J) is exactly the set of virtual arrows WJ . Also, note that D+E=T ,and that since D+ must extend D,D+J=DJ . Therefore the mapping above can be written equivalently as

WJ→C(T,DJ)

w↦D+w

which is in the desired form. Call this mapping ϕJ . Naturality in J is now the following commutative diagram for every morphism g:J→K of J ,(3.4)




which commutes by functoriality of D+ (recalling that D+g=Dg since g∈J ).

Conversely,consider a natural family of maps ϕJ:WJ→C(T,DJ) . Define now a weighted cone D+:J+W→C as follows:

  • On the objects and morphisms of J ,it agrees with D ;

  • D+E:=T ;

  • For every J and w:E→J (i.e. w∈WJ ), D+w:=ϕJ(w) .

To show that this is functorial, notice that identities are mapped to identities, and composition of morphisms of J is respected by functoriality of D . It only remains to show preservation of composition for arrows in the form E→J and J→K ,but this is guaranteed by naturality of ϕ , since it amounts to a commutative diagram analogous to (3.4).

Finally, as one can readily see, these two procedures are mutually inverse.

Lemma 3.6. Let D:J→C be a diagram,and let W:J→ Set be a functor. The presheaf

(3.5)Cop →Set

A↦[J,Set](W−,C(A,D−))

appearing in Definition 3.1 can be seen as mapping


  • Each object A of C to the set of W -weighted cones over D with tip A ;

  • Each arrow g:A→B in C to the function which pre-composes a cone D+ with g ,to give a cone g∗(D+) with tip A :




Dually,given a presheaf W:Jop → Set,the functor(3.6)

appearing in Definition 3.1 can be seen as mapping

  • On objects,an object A∈C to the set of W -weighted co-cones over D with tip A ;

  • On morphisms,given g:A→B in C ,the function which post-composes a cone with tip A with g to give a cone with tip B .

This motivates the following definition.

Definition 3.7. Let D:J→C be a diagram,and let W:J→ Set be a functor. We call the presheaf (3.5) the presheaf of W -weighted cones,and denote it by ConeW(D,−):Cop→ Set.

Dually,given a presheaf W:Jop → Set,we call the functor (3.6) the functor of W -weighted co-cones,and denote it by ConeW(D,−):C→ Set.

Proof of Lemma 3.6. As always, we will prove the case for cones, the co-cone case is completely analogous and dual.

First of all,on objects,given A∈C ,an element of the set [J,Set](W−,C(A,D−)) is by definition a natural transformation W⇒C(A,D−) between functors J→ Set. Once again by definition,this is a family of maps ϕJ:WJ→C(A,DJ) natural in J . We have seen in Lemma 3.5 that this is equivalently a W -weighted cone over D .

On morphisms,let g:A→B . The mapping

[J,Set](W−,C(B,D−))⇒g∗[J,Set](W−,C(A,D−))

is induced by (composing):

(i) Functoriality of C(−,D−) in its first (contravariant) argument,and

(ii) Functoriality of [J,Set](−,−) in its second (covariant) argument. That is:





So, under the correspondence of Lemma 3.5, the functorial action on morphisms corresponds to arrow-wise precomposition of weighted cones.

With this, we are now ready to prove the theorem.

Proof of Theorem 3.4. Once again we focus on the limit case, the colimit case is completely analogous and dual.

Consider the presheaf of W -weighted cones:

Cop →ConeW(D,−) Set 

A↦[J,Set](W−,C(A,D−))

Applying the Yoneda lemma,an object T representing ConeW(D,−) consists first of all of a distinguished ("universal") element c∈[J,Set](W−,C(T,D−)) ,the one corresponding to the identity under the bijection characterizing the universal property:

C(T,T)↔[J,Set](W−,C(T,D−))

idT↦c

By Lemma 3.6,we know that this is equivalently a W -weighted cone over D with tip T . Moreover, since by naturality of the isomorphism the following diagram must commute for every object A and


every u:A→T ,




and since the bottom arrow is a bijection,for every object A and every element f of the set [J,Set](W−,C(A,D−)) (i.e. weighted cone over A ),there exist a unique morphism u:A→T such that f=u∗c . Now again by Lemma 3.6, f=u∗c means exactly that f is obtained from c by arrow-wise precomposition.

To summarize, weighted limits and colimits are like ordinary limits and colimits, except that:

  • The cones have tuples of arrows instead of single arrows as their sides, as specified by the weighting;

  • Not every side triangle automatically commutes, instead, which triangles commute is again specified by the weighting.

Remark 3.8. Notice that the presheaves of weighted cones and cocones are functorial in D . This means that weighted limits and colimits, when enough of them exist, are functorial in the diagram, as it happens for ordinary limits and colimits.

Moreover, the presheaves of weighted cones and cocones (and hence the weighted limits and colimits, if they exist) are also contravariantly functorial in the weights. This is a phenomenon that has no analogue in the unweighted case. In what follows we will see some examples.

3.2 Basic examples


Let's see some basic examples of weighted limits used in the literature. We start with a simple one, which we examine in detail to build some intuition.

Example 3.9 (Power). When we form the product of an object X with itself,




we are using the same object, X ,twice. The universal property reads: we have (universal) maps π1,π2:X×X→X such that for every object A and every pair of maps f1,f2:A→X ,there exists a unique map f:A→X×X with π1∘f=f1 and π2∘f=f2 .


We can express the same universal property using X only once in the diagram,but replacing the cone (f1,f2) by a weighted cone:(3.7)




The price to pay is that this way, not every triangle in the diagram commutes. Indeed, if we want the universal property to read just as before,we want to say that π1∘f=f1 and π2∘f=f2 ,but not,for example,that π1∘f=f2 . (We will use the convention to label the arrows exactly in such a way that matching indices give commutative triangles, whenever possible.)

Let’s make this formal. Denote by1the one-object,one-arrow category,and denote its single object by 1 . Denote also by 2 the two-element set,and its elements by w1 and w2 . Consider now the following weighted one-object diagram.

1→XC1→2Set

1↦X

1↦2={w1,w2}

As a diagram,it has a single object, X ,and no arrows (except implicitly the identity). What’s interesting,here,is the weighted cones. 4 Indeed,a weighted cone has a tip A and two arrows A→X:




A weighted limit of this diagram is now a universal weighted cone. It is called a power, and is usually denoted as X2 . Denote its universal pair by π1,π2 . The universal property reads: for every weighted cone,i.e. for every object A and every pair of maps f1,f2:A→X ,there is a unique map f:A→X such that π1∘f=f1 and π2∘f=f2 : Notice that this is the same as the universal property of X×X ,as expressed through the diagram (3.7). Indeed, X2≅X×X ,as elementary algebra suggests.






4 Note that a non-weighted cone over this one-object diagram is just an arrow to X ,and the ordinary limit is just X (with the identity as limit cone).




Let’s now look at this in general. Let X be an object of C ,and let S be a set. The S -power or S -cartesian power or sometimes S -cotensor of X ,which we denote by XS ,is the weighted limit of the following (one-object) diagram and weight. 1→S Set 1↦S

Explicitly,we have a universal set of S -many arrows XS→X (the product projections),establishing a bijection between arrows A→XS and S -tuples of arrows A→X .

An alternative way to define XS ,which readily generalizes to the enriched context,is as follows. First of all,given a set T ,denote by TS the usual set cartesian power. (That is,either the S -fold cartesian product of T ,or equivalently the set of functions S→T . And yes,that is the cartesian power in C= Set.) Now for an object X of an arbitrary category C ,the power XS is equivalently an object representing the following presheaf,

Cop → Set 

A↦C(A,X)S

where C(A,X)S is the set cartesian power. Indeed,notice that its elements are exactly S -tuples of arrows A→X . More formally,the presheaf of weighted cones for W=S:1→ Set is

[1,Set](W−,C(A,D−))=Set(S,C(A,X))≅C(A,X)S.

A category is called powered or cotensored (over Set) if powers exist for all objects X and all sets S .

In a category with products,the power always exists,and is given by the S -fold categorical product. Indeed, notice that they represent naturally isomorphic presheaves:




Example 3.10 (Copower). Let’s now consider the dual case. Let X be an object of C ,and let S be a set. The S -copower or sometimes S -tensor of X ,which we denote by S⋅X ,is, similarly to the power,the weighted colimit of the one-object diagram X:1→C weighted by S:1op → Set. Explicitly,we have a universal set of S -many arrows X→S⋅X (the coproduct inclusions),establishing a bijection between arrows S⋅X→A and S -tuples of arrows X→A .

For example,if S=2={w1,w2} ,we have a universal pair of arrows 2⋅X→X (coproduct inclusions),establishing a bijection between (single) arrows 2⋅X→A and pairs of arrows X→A , where again we use the convention that we only require f∘ι1=f1 and f∘ι2=f2 ,and no other triangle to commute in general. Alternatively, S⋅X can be defined as an object representing the following functor,

C→Set

A↦C(X,A)S






where C(X,A)S is the set cartesian power (not copower). Indeed,its elements are exactly S -tuples of arrows X→A . A category is called copowered or tensored (over Set) if copowers exist for all objects X and all sets S .

In a category with coproducts,the power always exists,and is given by the S -fold coproduct. In particular,for C= Set,the copower is given by the cartesian product:

S⋅X≅∐s∈S⁡X=X+⋯+X⏟S many times ≅S×X.

Note that S⋅X≅S×X only for C= Set: in general,in the expression " S⋅X ", X is an object of C ,while S is a set. Therefore,the expression S×X is not meaningful in a generic category. 5

Example 3.11 (Weighted sum). In basic algebra, in a sum where some entries are repeated, for example x+x+y ,we can collect terms,and write for example 2⋅x+y . Using copowers,we can do something similar. Indeed, we can express a coproduct with repeated entries, equivalently, as a coproduct of copowers, or, as it is sometimes called, a weighted sum or weighted coproduct, 2⋅X+Y . (We use the same convention as in algebra,where ⋅ is applied before +.) We can depict its universal property as follows,




where as usual, not all possible triangles on the left commute in general, but only the corresponding ones as in Example 3.10. This is the colimit of a discrete diagram (indexed by a discrete category with two objects 2,as for a coproduct),but where the weight of X is a two-element set:

2→DC

2op →W Set (first object of2) 1↦X 1↦2 (two-element set) (second object of 2)2↦Y 2↦1 (one-element set) As basic algebra suggests, the resulting weighted colimit is isomorphic to the repeated coproduct:

2⋅X+Y≅X+X+Y.

To see why, notice that the functors they represent are naturally isomorphic:

A↦C(X,A)2×C(Y,A)⏟represented by 2⋅X+Y≅C(X,A)×C(X,A)×C(Y,A)⏟represented by X+X+Y



5 In the enriched case,one can replace Set by the enriching category.




More generally,given a set T ,denote by T the corresponding discrete category. Consider a discrete diagram D:T→C ,and a weighting W:Top → Set. The resulting weighted colimit looks indeed like a weighted sum in algebra,

∐t∈T⁡W(t)⋅D(t)

and is probably what inspired the terminology "weighted limit". It represents the following presheaf,

A↦∏t∈T⁡C(D(t),A)W(t)≅∏t∈T⁡C(D(t),A)×⋯×C(D(t),A)⏟W(t) many times 

and so it is isomorphic to a coproduct with repeated entries.

Example 3.12 (Weighted product). Similarly and dually to the previous example, we can form weighted products by means of products and powers. This is analogous to how, in algebra, x×x×y=x2×y . As in the example above,given a set T ,denote by T the corresponding discrete category. Consider a discrete diagram D:T→C ,and a weighting W:T→ Set. The resulting weighted limit looks like a monomial,

∏t∈T⁡D(t)W(t)

It represents the following presheaf,

A↦∏t∈T⁡C(A,D(t))W(t)≅∏t∈T⁡C(A,D(t))×⋯×C(A,D(t))⏟W(t) many times 

and so it is isomorphic to a product with repeated entries.

Example 3.13 (Kernel pair). 6 The kernel pair of a morphism f:X→Y is usually defined as the pullback of f with itself:




Similarly to the case of powers,also here the object X is used twice in the diagram,and so is f . Crucially,however,the arrows p1,p2:Ker(f)→X should be allowed to be different: for example, in categories such as Set,the kernel pair induces a relation on X denoting which elements of X can be distinguished by f ,and the two arrows denote the two legs of this relation,which is not always contained in the identity relation. 7



6 I learned this example from D. J. Myers.

7 Note that the usual notation for pullback of arrows,here,is misleading: both arrows would read as f∗f .




We can express the kernel pair as a universal weighted cone as follows,




where this time we require both triangles to commute, f∘p1=f∘p2=q . (And so,just like for pullbacks,we do not need to specify the map q .) That is,we have the following weighted diagram, where now Arr is the "walking arrow" category {0→1} :




The universal property now reads as follows:




For every triplet of arrows g1,g2:A→X and h:A→Y such that f∘g1=f∘g2=h (again, h is determined by g1 or g2 ),there exists a unique arrow g:A→Ker(f) such that p1∘g=g1 and p2∘g=g2 (and q∘g=h ,but that’s implied). This is the usual universal property of the kernel pair.

The cokernel pair, dually, can be expressed as a weighted colimit.

3.3 Core results


Before we look at more advanced examples, let's see some structural results about weighted limits and colimits.

The first result that we look at is known in the literature as "Yoneda reduction", "co-Yoneda lemma", or sometimes just "Yoneda lemma" (and "ninja Yoneda lemma" in [Lor21]). It says that the weighted limit with weights given by a representable set functor, is exactly the image of the representing object.


Proposition 3.14 (Yoneda reduction). For any functor D:J→C and every object J of J ,

limK∈J⁡⟨J(J,K),DK⟩≅DJ.

(Note that this is a limit weighted by the hom-functor J(J,−):J→ Set.) Similarly,and dually,

colimK∈J⟨J(K,J),DK⟩≅DJ.

A possible way to interpret this the following: if an object J is such that the "virtual arrows" of a set functor W correspond exactly to the arrows out of J ,then DJ ,together with the induced arrows, is a universal cone over the whole diagram. This generalizes the usual fact that, if the indexing category J has an initial object,its image is the (unweighted) limit of the diagram (or even, that if a set of numbers has a minimum element, then such element is necessarily the greatest lower bound).

Proof. As usual, we will consider the limit case. The limit in question has as weighting the hom functor J(J,−) . Therefore,the presheaf of weighted cones looks as follows,

A↦[J,Set](J(J,−),C(A,D−))≅C(A,DJ)

where the isomorphism is natural and follows from the Yoneda lemma. This means exactly that DJ represents the presheaf,and is hence the weighted limit by definition.

Another direct consequence of the Yoneda lemma is the following, sometimes stated as "every presheaf is a colimit of representable ones". In particular, it is a weighted colimit, weighted by itself. We look at the case of small categories, but if one properly takes care of size issues, similar things can be said more generally.

Proposition 3.15. Let C be a small category,and let F be a set functor on C . We can express F as the F -weighted limit in [C,Set]op of the Yoneda embedding Yon : C→[C,Set]op .

Dually,let P be a presheaf on C . Then P is the P -weighted colimit in [Cop,Set] of the Yoneda embedding Yon : C→[Cop,Set] .

Proof. As usual, let's focus on the functor case. By the Yoneda lemma, in the form (2.2), we have an isomorphism

[C,Set](F−,[C,Set]op(G, Yon −))≅[C,Set](F,G)

≅[C,Set]op(G,F)

natural in G . This says exactly that F represents the presheaf of F -weighted cones over Yon : C→ [C,Set]op ,and so F is the desired weighted limit.

Let's now look at how "weighted limits are limits". In all the examples we saw in the previous section, you may have noticed that all the weighted limits and colimits could also be expressed as ordinary, non-weighted limits and colimits. For example, the power could be expressed as an iterated product. This is a general phenomenon:

Theorem 3.16. Every weighted limit in a category C can be expressed as an ordinary limit (of a different diagram).

Dually, every weighted colimit can be expressed as an ordinary colimit.


One may then ask, why are weighted limits important? There are two main reasons:

(i) Often, expressing something as a weighted limit gives more compact expressions which reveal interesting properties. We will see examples of this in the next sections;

(ii) In enriched category theory, not all weighted limits can be expressed as ordinary limits, and in most cases, it's the theory of weighted limits which generalizes to the enriched context.

Let's now prove the theorem. We first start with a definition.

Definition 3.17. Let W:J→ Set be a set functor. The category of elements of W ,which we denote by El(W) ,is defined as follows.

  • Objects are pairs(J,w)where J is an object of J ,and w is an element of the set WJ ;

  • Morphisms (J,w)→(K,u) are morphisms g:J→K of J such that the function g∗:WJ→ WK maps w∈WJ to u∈WK .

Dually,for a presheaf W:Jop → Set,its category of elements El(W) has

  • As objects,again pairs(J,w)with J∈J ,and w∈WJ ;

  • As morphisms (J,w)→(K,u) ,morphisms g:J→K of J such that the function g∗:WK→ WJ maps u∈WK to w∈WJ (notice the directions of the arrows).

In both cases,denote by Π:El(W)→J the forgetful functor mapping(J,w)to J and g : (J,w)→(K,u) to g:J→K .

We can view the category of elements as a category of all possible "paths" from the virtual object to the objects of J . Indeed,we can view a pair(J,w),with w:∙→J ,as a copy of J which "keeps track of how we got there". Graphically it is helpful to consider the category El(W) as equipped with the terminal weight functor (singletons),this way we can view El(W) as a way of splitting apart parallel virtual arrows:





And so, in particular, it splits apart weighted cones into their separate commutative triangles:



(3.8)


Here is the precise statement.

Lemma 3.18. Let D:J→C be a diagram with weighting W:J→ Set. For every object A of C ,and naturally in A ,there is a bijective correspondence between

  • W -weighted cones over D ,and

  • Ordinary cones over the diagram

El(W)→ΠJ→DC

indexed by the category of elements.

Dually,given a presheaf W:Jop →Set ,there is a natural bijection between W -weighted co-cones over D and ordinary co-cones over the diagram D∘Π:El(W)→J→C .

Proof. As usual, let's focus on the cone case.

Let D+:J+W→C be a W -weighted cone over D with tip A . Construct now a (traditional) cone c=El∗(D+) over D∘Π:El(W)→J→C as follows. First of all,notice that the diagram D∘Π:El(W)→J→C maps an object(J,w)of D necessarily to DJ . Now set for all (J,w)∈El(W)

c(J,w):=D+w:A→DJ.

(It may helpful to look at the diagram in (3.8).) To see that this is a cone, note that for every morphism g:(J,w)→(K,w′) of El(W) (such that g∗w=w′ ) we have that,by functoriality of D+ ,

Dg∘c(J,w)=D+g∘D+w=D+(g∘w)=D+w′=c(K,w′)





This establishes a mapping

ConeW(D,A)→El∗Cone1(D∘Π,A).

It remains to show that this map is bijective and natural in A .

To show that it is injective,suppose that for cones D+ and D+′ we have c=El∗(D+)= El∗(D+) . Then for all J∈J and w∈WJ ,

D+w=c(J,w)=D+′w,

i.e. the weighted cones have exactly the same arrows,so D+=D+′ .

To show that it is surjective,let c=(c(J,w):A→DJ)(J,w)∈El(W) be a (traditional) cone over D∘Π . Then we can write it as El∗(D+) where for J∈J and w∈WJ,D+w=c(J,w) . To show that this is a weighted cone,i.e. that it is a functor D+:J+W→C ,notice that for every w∈WJ (or w:E→J ) and for all g:J→K ,

D+(g∘w)=c(K,g∗w)=Dg∘c(J,w)=D+g∘D+w,

using the fact that c is a cone.

Finally,to show that it is natural,let f:A→B . Then the following diagram commutes,

ConeW(D,B)→El∗Cone1(D∘Π:B)

f∗

ConeW(D,A)→El∗Cone1(D∘Π,A)

since both vertical arrows just precompose the arrows of the cones with f .

Proof of Theorem 3.16. (As usual, we will focus on the limit case.)

By Lemma 3.18,the presheaves ConeW(D,−) and Cone1(D∘Π,−):Cop → Set are naturally isomorphic. Therefore one is representable if and only if the other one is, and in that case their representing objects are isomorphic. By definition, the representing objects are respectively the W -weighted limit of D and the ordinary limit of D∘Π ,which must then coincide.

Corollary 3.19. A category has all (small) weighted limits if and only if it has all (small) ordinary limits, and a functor preserves all (small) weighted limits if and only if it preserves all (small) ordinary limits.

The same can be said about colimits.


Corollary 3.20. Just as ordinary limits and colimits, weighted limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise.

Finally, we present a weighted version of the famous result that hom functors preserve limits.

Theorem 3.21. Hom-functors preserve weighted limits and colimits in the same way as they preserve ordinary limits and colimits. More in detail,given D:J→C and W:J→Set ,if the weighted limit exists, then we have a natural isomorphism

C(A,limJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,DJ⟩)≅limJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,C(A,DJ)⟩

preserving the universal weighted cone.

Dually,given a presheaf W:Jop → Set,if the weighted colimit of D exists,we have a natural isomorphism

C(colimJ∈J⟨WJ,DJ⟩,A)≅limJ∈Jop ⁡⟨WJ,C(DJ,A)⟩

preserving the universal weighted co-cone.

(Note that a presheaf W:Jop → Set can be equivalently written as W:(Jop )→ Set,i.e. as a set functor on Jop  ,indexing a weighted limit - and vice versa.)

The proof follows closely the one for the unweighted case.

Proof. As usual,let’s consider the case of limits. Denote the weighted limit in C by L ,and denote the arrows of the universal weighted cone by cJ,w:L→DJ ,for J∈J and w∈WJ . We have to show that C(A,L) is a weighted limit in Set,with the induced cone:




To this end,let S be a cone over C(A,D−) ,and denote by dJ,w:S→C(A,DJ) the arrows of the cone (for J∈J and w∈WJ ). We have to show that there is a unique function u:S→C(A,L) such that for all J∈J and w∈WJ,cJ,w∘u=dJ,u .(3.9)





Note now that the function dJ,w:S→C(A,DJ) is an S -indexed tuple of arrows A→DJ . For each s∈S ,the element dJ,w(s) is an arrow A→DJ ,and if we keep s fixed and vary J∈J and w∈WJ ,the tuple (dJ,w(s))J∈J,w∈WJ is exactly a weighted cone in C . By the universal property of L ,to this tuple there corresponds a unique morphism u~s:A→L ,such that for all J and w ,

(3.10)cJ,w∘u~s=dJ,w(s).

We therefore define our map u:S→C(A,L) as follows:

u(s):=u~s∈C(A,L).

This way,by (3.10),the triangles as in (3.9) commutes. To see that the map u is unique,suppose that another map u′:S→C(A,L) makes the triangle (3.9) commute. Then for all s∈S ,the element u′(s)∈C(A,L) ,which is an arrow A→L ,is such that for all J and w,cJ,w∘u′(s)=dJ,w(s) . But we know,by the universal property of L ,that only one possible map A→L with this property, namely u~s . So necessarily u′(s)=u~s ,which means that u′=u .

3.4 Weighted (co)limits as (co)ends


In the last few years it has become very common to write weighted limits and colimits in the following way.

(3.11)limJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,DJ⟩≅∫J∈JDJWJcolimJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,DJ⟩≅∫J∈JWJ⋅DJ

Inside the integral signs we can recognize powers and copowers. The integral signs themselves are not actual integrals in the sense of analysis, they denote particular limits and colimits called ends and coends.

Let's now see what these symbols mean. There are at least three levels of understanding them:

(i) At the most shallow level, one could consider the expressions in (3.11) simply as an alternative way of writing weighted limits and colimits in categories such as Set.

(ii) One can describe ends and coends in terms of weighted limits and colimits. This will be the topic of the present section.

(iii) Ends and coends have their own very deep theory, interesting for its own sake. The standard reference for that is the book [Lor21], to which we refer the interested readers.

Let’s get to (ii). Let D:J→C be a diagram with weighting W:J→ Set,and consider its weighted limit. For every object J of J ,any W -weighted cone,for example the universal one,gives a tuple of arrows from the tip T to DJ indexed by the set WJ .





Now suppose that the category C has powers. By definition of power,a WJ -indexed tuple of arrows T→DJ corresponds naturally to a single arrow T→DJWJ :




We can now do this for all the objects of J . We want to express T as a particular limit (an end,as we will see) of the DJWJ ,instead of as a weighted limit of the DJ . Now,for each morphism g:J→K of J ,we could try to induce from the morphism Dg:DJ→DK a morphism DJWJ→DKWK , forming a new diagram "parallel" to the original one:




Things are however not so simple. Indeed,from Dg we could induce a morphism DJWJ→DKWJ , with the same exponent,but not DJWJ→DKWK . What we can do,however,is induce a pair of morphisms (called a cospan) as follows:




This is due to the fact that the power DKWJ is functorial in K ,and contravariantly functorial in J . To see how,in detail,let’s first fix some terminology.

Definition 3.22. A bifunctor B:C×D→E is a functorial assignment in both variables,




where moreover the following diagram commutes for all morphisms c:C→C′ of C and d:D→D′


of D :(3.12)




(Equivalently,it is a functor on the product category C×D .)

We will also call a bidiagram a bifunctor in the form Jop ×J→C . A canonical example is the hom functor J(−,−) .

Lemma 3.23. Let C be a category with powers.

(i) For every set S ,the assignment X↦XS extends canonically to a functor (−)S:C→C .

(ii) For every object X of C ,the assignment S↦XS extends canonically to a functor X(−) : Setop→C .

(iii) The two assignment make the following diagram commute for all functions f:S→T and morphisms g:X→Y ,




giving a bifunctor P:Setop ×C→C .

Dually,let C be a category with copowers. The assignment (S,X)↦S⋅X is a bifunctor P:Set×C→C .

The result could be seen as following directly from functoriality of the cone presheaves, as we saw in Remark 3.8. We give a direct proof here, which will hopefully provide additional clarity.

Proof of Lemma 3.23. First, let's start with the power case.

(i) Let S be a set,and let g:X→Y be a morphism of C . For every s∈S ,denote by cX,s:XS→X be the s -th arrow of the weighted cone of XS ,and by cY,s:YS→Y be the s -th arrow of the weighted cone of YS . Consider now the following diagram.




We have that for every s∈S ,the composition g∘cX,s gives an arrow XS→Y . We therefore have an S -tuple of arrows XS→Y ,which by the universal property of YS must factor uniquely through the weighted cone of Y . That is,there exists a unique morphism u:XS→YS such that for all s∈S,g∘cX,s=cY,s∘u . We denote this u by gS:XS→YS , which gives the action on morphisms of the desired functor C→C . Functoriality follows from uniqueness of u .


(ii) Let X be an object of C ,and let f:S→T be a function. Similarly to above,for s∈S denote by cX,s:XS→X be the s -th arrow of the weighted cone of XS ,and for t∈T denote by cX,t′:XT→X be the t -th arrow of the weighted cone of XT . Construct now an S -tuple of arrows (ds:XT→X)s∈S as follows (mind that we used both S and T ): for each s∈S , we set ds=cX,f(s):XT→X . In other words,for t∈T ,

  • If f−1(t) has a single element s∈S ,the map cX,t′:XT→X will appear in the tuple (ds)s∈S exactly once,namely,as the s -th entry;

  • If f−1(t) is a set with several elements,the map cX,t′:XT→X will appear in the tuple (ds)s∈S exactly as many times as the elements of f−1(t) ;

  • If f−1(t) is empty,the map cX,t′:XT→X will not appear in the tuple (ds)s∈S .




Now by the universal property of XS ,there exists a unique map u:XT→XS such that for all s∈S,ds=cX,s∘u=cX,f(s)′∘u :




We denote this map by Xf:XT→XS ,which gives the action on morphisms of the desired functor Setop →C . Again,functoriality follows from the uniqueness of u .

(iii) Consider the following diagram,where we consider S -many arrows XS→S and YS→Y (the universal weighted cones),as well as also S -many arrows XT→X and YT→X (the


ones we constructed in (ii) above.)(3.13)




We have to prove that the top parallelogram commutes. Let's first show that all other faces commute for all s :

  • First of all,the front (lower) parallelogram commutes,since by definition of gS in (i), g∘cX,s=cY,s∘gS;

  • The left and right triangles commute by definition of Xf and Yf in (ii);

  • Finally,the back parallelogram commutes,since for every s∈S,cY,t′∘gT=g∘cX,t′ . This follows from the definition of gT as in (i),where for every t∈T,cY,t′∘gT=g∘cX,t′ .

This means that for all s∈S ,

cY,s∘gS∘Xf=cY,s∘Yf∘gT.

In other words,either path in the top of the diagram,post-composed with cY,s ,gives the same map to Y . Since this is true for all s ,we have a weighted cone over Y ,and hence a unique map XT→YS making the whole diagram commute. This implies that gS∘Xf=∘Yf∘gT .

It might be also helpful to sketch (ii) for the copower case. Given X∈C and a function f:S→T ,from the T -tuple of arrows (ct:X→T⋅X)t∈T we can create the S -tuple of arrows (cf(s):X→T⋅X)s∈S . By the universal properties of copowers,this induces a unique map S⋅X→T⋅X .
