compatible with the original diagram dually to above.

Let's now come back to our original weighted limit, expressed in terms of powers. By the previous corollary we have a pair of arrows as follows.(3.15)




Moreover, as we will show, the diamond above commutes. Let's again fix some terminology.

Definition 3.25. A wedge over a bidiagram B:Jop ×J→C is an object T together with arrows cJ:T→B(J,J) for all objects J∈J ,such that for every morphism g:J→K of J ,the following diagram commutes:




A co-wedge is an object T together with arrows cJ:B(J,J)→T such that for every g:J→K the following diagram commutes:




Remark 3.26. Notice that a wedge over B ,in general:

  • is not a cone over B (seeing B as a diagram indexed by Jop ×J ): it only has arrows to the `"diagonal"` objects T→B(J,J) ,and not,for example, T→B(J,K) for J≠K ;

  • is also not exactly a weighted cone,weighted by the empty set at J≠K : a weighted cone would need to have,for all morphisms g:J→K of J ,also an arrow as the one in the middle,


making both triangles commute:




Indeed, recall that "a virtual arrow can be composed with a real arrow and give another virtual arrow". (We would have a single arrow for both triangles, since the diamond commutes.) However, if we take into account those induced arrows, we do obtain a weighted cone canonically, see Lemma 3.35.

Remark 3.27. Wedges, just as cones and cocones, are closed under precomposition with morphisms of C . Therefore they define a presheaf on C ,analogous to the one of cones. Let’s denote it by Wedge(B,−):Cop → Set.

We can now make the diamond in (3.15) commute:

Lemma 3.28. Let C be a category with powers. Let D:J→C be a diagram weighted by W:J→ Set,and consider the bidiagram BD,W:Jop ×J→ Set constructed in Corollary 3.24. Given an object T of C ,there is a bijection between

(i) W -weighted cones over D with tip T ,and

(ii) wedges over BD,W with tip T .

This bijection is moreover natural in T ,as it commutes with precomposition by arrows of C .

Proof. Consider the diagram (3.14) involving D and BD,W ,where the respective paths commute. As we saw in the beginning of this section,a W -weighted cone over D consists first of all of,for each J ,a WJ -indexed tuple of arrows (tJ(w):T→DJ)w∈WJ . These are in bijection with single arrows T→DJWJ ,let’s call these arrows zJ :




We now have to show that the (zJ)J∈J form a wedge over BD,W if and only if the (tJ(w):T→ DJ)w∈WJ,J∈J form a weighted cone. That is,chasing the diagram above,we have to show that the top diamond commutes if and only if the respective paths in the back tall triangle commute:


  • First of all,suppose that (tJ(w):T→DJ)w∈WJ,J∈J is a weighted cone. That is,for every g:J→K of J and every w∈WJ,tJ(w)=Dg∘tK(g∗w) . Therefore

cK(w)∘DgWJ∘zJ=Dg∘cJ(w)∘zJ

=Dg∘tJ(w)

=tK(g∗w)

=cK(g∗w)∘zK

=cK(w)∘DKWg∘zK.

Since the equality above holds for every w∈WJ ,we have equal tuples of arrows T→DK , which means equal single arrows T:DKWK . That is,

DgWJ∘zJ=DKWg∘zK.

This holds for all g ,which means that we have a wedge.

  • Conversely,suppose that (zJ)J∈J is wedge. Then for all g:J→K,DgWJ∘zJ=DKWg∘ zK . Therefore for all w∈WJ ,

Dg∘tJ(w)=Dg∘cJ(w)∘zJ

=cK(w)∘DgWJ∘zJ

=cK(w)∘DKWg∘zK

=cK(g∗w)∘zK

=tK(g∗w),

which means that we have a weighted cone.

Naturality, i.e. compatibility with precomposition, is immediate.

Keeping again our main task in mind, we now want to say that if we start with a weighted limit cone, the resulting wedge is universal too. Here is the precise term for that.

Definition 3.29. An end of a bidiagram B:Jop ×J→C ,if it exists,is a terminal wedge,and

is denoted by

∫J∈JB(J,J)

Explicitly,it means that given any wedge T′ over B there exists a unique morphism u making the following diagram commute: Dually, a coend is an initial co-wedge, and is denoted by






Equivalently,an end is a representing object for the presheaf Wedge(B, -)of Remark 3.27.

Coming back again to our weighted colimit (3.15),we are finally ready to express T as limit of powers: it's their end. Here is the precise statement.

Theorem 3.30. Let C be a category with (small) powers. Let D:J→C be a functor with weights

W:J→ Set. Then

limJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,DJ⟩≅∫J∈JDJWJ.

Dually,let C be a category with (small) copowers. Let D:J→C be a functor with weights

W:Jop → Set. Then

colimJ∈J⟨WJ,DJ⟩≅∫J∈JWJ⋅DJ.

Proof. Lemma 3.28 gives a natural bijection between Wedge (BD,W,−) and ConeW(D,−) . Therefore the representing objects,if they exist,are isomorphic,and so a W -weighted limit of D is equivalently an end of BD,W .

Because of this theorem, it is very common, in categories such as Set, to write weighted limits and colimits as ends and coends of powers and copowers.

Example 3.31. The Yoneda reduction for a functor D:J→C (Proposition 3.14) can be expressed as follows,provided C has powers and copowers:

∫J∈JDKJ(J,K)≅DJ≅∫J∈JJ(K,J)⋅DK.

Remark 3.32. Compare the cones of a weighted product (Example 3.12) and of a kernel pair (Example 3.13):




We see that in the first case, the cone simply consists of a collection of "projection" arrows, while in the second case, not any collection of arrows counts as a cone: it needs to make some triangles commute. (The situation is analogous in the case of ordinary limits: a limit is like a product, but some triangles must commute in addition.) Let's look at this in general: consider the difference between a weighted product and a generic weighted limit, expressed as an end of powers:

∏t∈T⁡D(t)W(t) vs. ∫J∈JDJWJ

If we replace the end sign by a product, we get exactly a weighted product (indexed by the objects of J ). So,a possible interpretation of an end is that it is like a product,except that some additional things must commute. These additional constraints come from the morphisms of J . (In Set,as usual for limits, we have a subset of a product.)


Similarly, weighted colimits, expressed as coends of copowers, are similar to weighted sums (Example 3.11):

∐t∈TW(t)⋅D(t) vs. ∫J∈JWJ⋅DJ

Again,the difference is that on the right-hand side some triangles,induced by the morphisms of J , must commute. (In Set, as usual for colimits, we have a quotient of a disjoint union.) This idea that a coend is almost like a sum is possibly the reason why it is customary to write it with an integral sign: after all,an integral is also almost like a sum. 8

Ends and coends are also interesting beyond the case of Theorem 3.30: they are more than just a convenient presentation of weighted limits. Here is an example of an end which is not (on the nose) in the form of Theorem 3.30. For way more theory and examples, see [Lor21].

Example 3.33 (Set of natural transformations). Let C be a small category,and consider functors F,G:C→D . The set of natural transformations F⇒G is given by the following end:

∫c∈CD(FC,GC).

To see this,consider a one-point set forming a wedge over the bidiagram D(F−,G−) : First of all we need for all C∈C a function αC:1→D(FG,GC) ,i.e. a morphism αC:FC→GC of D . Moreover,for every morphism c:C→C′ ,the following diagram has to commute.




This means precisely that the arrows αC need to make the following diagram commute:




This needs to hold for all c:C→C′ ,that is,they need to form a natural transformation. The end is then the set of all of them.

To conclude this section, let's give an equivalent definition of ends and coends as particular weighted limits and colimits.



8 There are deeper analogies between coends and integrals,which are beyond the scope of this work. Some of them were explored in [Lor21], some of them in [PT22], and some of them still remain to be explored.




Theorem 3.34. Let B:Jop ×J→C . The end of B ,if it exists,is equivalently the weighted limit

∫J∈JB(J,J)≅limJ,K⁡⟨J(J,K),B(J,K)⟩.

The coend of B ,if it exists,is equivalently the weighted colimit

∫J∈JB(J,J)≅colimJ,K⟨J(K,J),B(J,K)⟩.

The main argument in the proof is given by the following statement, which we hinted at in Remark 3.26.

Lemma 3.35. Let B:Jop ×J→C be a bifunctor. There is a bijection between

(i) wedges over B (with tip T ),and

(ii) cones over B (with tip T ),seeing B as a diagram,weighted by the hom-functor:

Jop ×J→W Set 

(J,K)↦J(J,K).

This bijection is moreover natural in T .

Proof of Lemma 3.35. Let (zJ:T→B(J,J))J∈J be a wedge. As hinted at in Remark 3.26,we can complete it to a weighted cone. In order to have a cone with the desired weighting, we need first of all assignments as follows for all J,K∈J .

J(J,K)→cJ,KC(T,B(J,K)).

That is,for every g:J→K of J we need an arrow cJ,K(g):T→B(J,K) of C . We then need to show that this assignment is natural in J and K . Let’s now define cJ,K from the wedge (zJ) as the unique vertical arrow making the following diagram commute,(3.16)




that is, we set

cJ,K:=B(J,g)∘zJ=B(g,K)∘zK,

where the last equality holds since (zJ) is a wedge. Note that this gives potentially several arrows T→B(J,K) (not necessarily distinct),one for each g:J→K . In particular,for J=K ,we potentially get several arrows T→B(J,J) ,induced by the endomorphisms J→J . (The arrow of the wedge cJ is the one induced by the identity of J .) To see that our assignment is natural in J , let j:J→J′ be a morphism of J . Then the following diagram commutes,





by (contravariant) functoriality of B in the first variable. Naturality in K is similar. Therefore, (cJ,K) is a weighted cone.

Conversely,let (cJ,K)J,K∈J be a weighted cone. We can extract a wedge (zJ)J∈J by setting

zJ:=cJ,J(idJ).

To see that this is indeed a wedge,notice that for all g:J→K of J ,notice that

B(J,g)∘zJ=B(J,g)∘cJ,J(idJ)=cJ,K(g)=B(g,K)∘cK,K(idK)=B(g,K)∘zK,

where the middle equalities follow from the fact that c is a weighted cone (i.e. it makes triangles analogous to the ones in (3.16) commute).

This way we have the desired bijection between wedges and weighted cones with tip T . Naturality in T now means that this bijection respects precomposition of cones and wedges with morphisms T′→T .

Proof of Theorem 3.34. By Lemma 3.35,the presheaf Wedge(B, -)is naturally isomorphic to the one of weighted cones over B (weighted by the hom functor). Therefore the representing objects must coincide.

3.5 Pointwise Kan extensions


An important special case of weighted limits and colimits are pointwise Kan extensions.

Let's briefly review ordinary Kan extensions. (For the readers who are unfamiliar with them, we recommend [Rie16, Chapter 6].)

Let D:J→C and G:J→K be functors. A right Kan extension of D along G is a functor R:K→C together with a natural transformation ρ:R∘G⇒D such that for every (other) functor F:K→C and natural transformation α:F∘I⇒D there exists a unique natural transformation ν:F⇒R such that the following equality holds.






Dually,a left Kan extension is a functor L:K→C natural transformation λ:D⇒R∘G such that for every F:K→C and α:D⇒F∘G there exists a unique ν:L⇒F such that the following holds.




Pointwise Kan extensions are now particularly well behaved Kan extensions.

Definition 3.36. Let D:J→C and G:J→K be functors.

  • A right Kan extension R of D along G is pointwise if for all objects K of K ,

(3.17)RK≅limJ∈J⁡⟨K(K,GJ),DJ⟩.

  • A left Kan extension L of D along G is pointwise if for all objects K of K ,

(3.18)LK≅colimJ∈J⟨K(GJ,K),DJ⟩.

Once again, the definition at first might not look particularly suggestive. So let's interpret this in our usual way. The idea is that the weight functor (resp. presheaf),i.e. the "virtual arrows in J ", come from real arrows of K ,in the form K→GJ :





That is,the virtual arrows to J are exactly modeled after the real arrows K→GJ in K . Now the weighted limit of D with these weights is a universal weighted cone with this shape,i.e. we are trying to optimally (terminally) fit arrows like the ones in K from K to the image of J ,except that we are in the category C :(3.19)




Let's now check that this definition indeed gives us a Kan extension in the usual sense.

Theorem 3.37. Any functor R:K→C satisfying (3.17),and where its action on morphisms is induced by the universal property, is necessarily a right Kan extension.

Dually,any functor L:K→C satisfying (3.18),and where its action on morphisms is induced by the universal property, is necessarily a left Kan extension.

Proof of Theorem 3.37. Let R:K→C be satisfying (3.17). To show that R is a right Kan extension in the usual sense,we first of all have to give a natural transformation ρ:R∘G⇒D . In components,we need maps ρJ:RGJ→DJ . Now instantiating (3.19) for K=GJ ,the identity GJ→GJ gives a distinguished arrow among the (possibly many) ones of the limit cone:



We take that as our component ρJ . (Naturality holds since the analogous diagram commutes in J .)



Let’s now turn to the universal property of the Kan extension. Consider F and ϕ as follows.




We have to show that there is a unique natural transformation ν:F⇒D+ such that ρ∘(νG)=ϕ . We can depict F and ϕ as follows.




Recall now that RK is a terminal weighted cone for all K∈K . If we postcompose the arrows FK→FGJ with the components ϕJ:FGJ→DJ ,we get a weighted cone over D with tip FK . Therefore,since RK is a weighted limit,there is a unique map FK→RK making the respective paths in the following diagram commute:





We take this map as the component at K of the natural transformation ν:F⇒R . Naturality follows from the universal property,and moreover,setting K=GJ in the diagram above and chasing it,




we have that ρJ∘νGJ=ϕJ∘id=ϕJ . That holds for all J ,so that

ρ∘(νG)=ϕ,

making (R,ρ) a right Kan extension.

To conclude this section, looking at the diagrams (3.3), which we re-propose:





one may suspect that weighted cones and cocones are actually Kan extensions. They are, and pointwise too.

Theorem 3.38. Let D:J→C be a diagram weighted by W:J→ Set. A W -weighted limit cone of D is exactly a pointwise right Kan extension of D along the inclusion functor I:J→J+W :




Dually,given W:Jop → Set,a W -weighted colimit cone of D is exactly a pointwise left Kan extension of D along the inclusion I :





To prove the theorem we use the following result, which might be interesting on its own:

Lemma 3.39. The universal natural transformation ( ρ or λ ) of a pointwise (left or right) Kan extension along a fully faithful functor is a natural equivalence.

Proof of Lemma 3.39. As usual,let’s prove the limit (i.e. right) case. Let G:J→K be a fully faithful functor. The pointwise right Kan extension of D:J→C along G ,on an object K ,is given by

R(K)≅limJ′∈J⁡⟨K(K,GJ′),DJ′⟩.

Therefore the composition R∘G ,on an object J of J ,is given by

RGJ≅limJ′∈J⁡⟨K(GJ,GJ′),DJ′⟩

≅limJ′∈J⁡⟨J(J,J′),DJ′⟩

≅DJ

using the fact that G is fully faithful and the Yoneda reduction (Proposition 3.14). The arrow ρJ:RGJ→DJ is now given by this isomorphism.

Proof of Theorem 3.38. As usual, let's focus on the limit case. By Lemma 3.39, up to natural isomorphism we have that the natural transformation ρ can be taken to be the identity. That is, the functor D+ is actually an extension of D ,it agrees with D on the objects of J . On the only other object E we now have,by definition of pointwise Kan extension,

D+(E)≅limJ⁡⟨J+W(E,DJ),DJ⟩

=limJ⁡⟨WJ,DJ⟩

i.e. exactly the W -weighted limit of D ,with the arrows E→DJ mapped to the arrows of the universal limit cone.

3.6 Functor pairing


We now turn out attention to the prototypical example of a weighted colimit of sets, the pairing. As sets have copowers, this weighted colimit is usually expressed as a coend, and several coends appearing in the literature are instances of pairings. We will see it for example in Cauchy completions (Section 4), as well as in the composition of profunctors and in the Day convolution of presheaves (see Section 5).

Definition 3.40. Let C be a small category. Consider a presheaf P:Cop→ Set and a set functor F:C→ Set. Their pairing (or sometimes tensor product,but this name may mean other things too) is the set

(3.20)⟨P,F⟩:=colimC∈C⟨PC,FC⟩≅∫C∈CPC⋅FC≅∫C∈CPC×FC,

where we recall that, in Set, the copower is equivalently the product.


Let's now interpret this in terms of virtual arrows. So far we have been looking at adding extra arrows to a category C only in a "fixed" direction.

The pairing of a functor and a presheaf is best interpreted using both directions: virtual arrows to our category (the functor F:C→Set ),and from our category (the presheaf P:Cop →Set ):




The pairing ⟨P,F⟩ can now be seen as the set of "virtual paths" ∙−→∙ in the diagram above,with equal paths counted only once.

Let’s see what we mean. The simplest way of forming a path ∙→∙ is to have,at an object A of C ,a virtual arrow f:∙→A (i.e. an element f∈FA ) and a virtual arrow p:A→∙ (i.e. an element p∈PA) :

-→fA→⋯→p∙

So one first way of defining all possible paths ∙−→∙ is to take all possible pairs (f∈FA,p∈PA) for all objects A :




That would be the set9

∐A∈C⁡PA×FA

Things are however not so simple. Given g:A→B in C ,consider an element f∈FA (i.e. a virtual arrow f:∙→A ) and an element p∈PB (i.e. a virtual arrow p:B→∙ ): the form a path ∙⇢∙ as follows.

-→fA→gB→−pB

This "three-arrow path" was already counted before, since we can express it as a "two-arrow path",



9 Recall that we are assuming C is small.




but we can do so in two ways,namely,as p∘(g∗f) and as (g∗p)∘f :




Therefore, the pairs

(g∗p,f)∈PA×FA and (p,g∗f)∈PB×FB

should be considered equivalent. In other words, we want to take the quotient set

(3.21)(∐A∈C⁡PA×FA)/∼

where ∼ is the equivalence relation generated by

(g∗p,f)∈PA×FA∼(p,g∗f)∈PB×FB

for all f∈FA and p∈PB and all morphisms g:A→B of C . We can see (3.21) as the set of all virtual paths ∙→∙ ,without double-counting. We will denote each equivalence class as follows:

[A,g∗p,f]=[B,p,g∗f].

Remark 3.41. One may now ask: what about four-arrow paths, and more? These are already accounted for: in the sequence

∙→fA0→g1A1→g2…→gnAn→p∙

one can always replace g1,…,gn by their composite,which is a single morphism.

Let’s now show that the pairing of F and P is exactly this set.

Theorem 3.42. Let C be a small category. Given F:C→ Set and P:Cop → Set,their pairing ⟨P,F⟩ is given up to isomorphism by the set (3.21).

Proof. We can for example show that the set (3.21) gives the coend in (3.40). So let's first of all show that if forms a co-wedge,i.e. that for all g:A→B of C ,the following diagram commutes, where the unlabeled arrows are the inclusions PA×FA↪∐A⁡PA×FA followed by the quotient map. Starting with (p∈PB,f∈FA) ,






we see that the diagram commutes precisely by how we define the equivalence relation.

To see that this co-wedge is universal,consider a family of functions (zA:PA×FA→X)A∈C . By the universal property of coproducts, such a family is equivalently given by a function on the disjoint union z:∐A⁡PA×FA→X . Suppose now that the zA form a wedge,i.e. that for all g:A→B ,the following diagram commutes.




This means precisely that for all f∈FA and p∈B,zA(g∗p,f)=zB(p,g∗f) . That is,the function z:∐A⁡PA×FA→X is invariant within each equivalence class. Therefore it factors uniquely through the quotient (3.21).

Before we leave this section,it can be helpful to what happens if P and F are representable: in that case, all the "virtual" arrows are actually real, and the pairing recovers the usual composition of arrows:

Example 3.43. Let X and Y be objects of a category C . Consider the functor C(X,−):C→ Set (of arrows from X ) and the presheaf C(−,Z) (of arrows into Z ). Their pairing,up to isomorphism, is the set of arrows from X to Z :

⟨C(X,−),C(−,Z)⟩=colimY∈C⁡⟨C(X,Y),C(Y,Z)⟩≅C(X,Z).

Indeed, the isomorphism is exactly an instance of Yoneda reduction (Proposition 3.14).


  • All other cases are obtained by iterating the arguments we have just made. Finally, let's turn to unitality. Again, we distinguish a few cases. - All identities of objects of C behave like identities with all morphisms of C . - For every object A of C and every morphisms f:E→A ,we have

idA∘f=(idA)∗f=f

by functoriality of F . Similarly,for every morphism p:A→E we have p∘idA=p by functoriality of P .

  • To show that i=[X,π,ι] is the identity of E ,let f:E→A . Then using (4.4) and (4.2),

f∘[X,π,ι]=c(π,f)∗ι=f.

Similarly,given p:A→E ,

[X,π,ι]∘p=c(p,ι)∗π=p.

This makes C′ a category.

Let’s now look at the situation where,in some sense,"the extra point is already in C :

Theorem 4.4. Given a Cauchy point(F,P,c,i)of C ,the following conditions are equivalent.

(i) The functor F is representable,and represented by an object R ;

(ii) The presheaf P is representable,and represented by an object R ;

(iii) The inclusion I:C→C′ is an equivalence of categories.

Definition 4.5. We say that a Cauchy point of C is already in C if any of the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4.4 are satisfied.

A category is called Cauchy complete if every Cauchy point is already in it.

The definition is similar to Cauchy completions of metric spaces: in a certain sense, a category, like a metric space, is Cauchy complete if "all the points that should be there are indeed there". This analogy can be made mathematically precise in terms of enriched categories, but that is beyond the scope of this exposition. (See for example [BD86].)

To prove the theorem we will make use of the following lemma.

Lemma 4.6. Given a Cauchy point(F,P,c,i),the following conditions are equivalent.

(i) F is representable;

(ii) P is representable;

(iii) There exists a representative (X,π,ι) of the equivalence class i such that c(p,ι)=idX .




Moreover,if the conditions above are satisfied, X is a representing object.


Proof. Let’s start with (iii) ⇒(i) : Notice that "virtual precomposition" with π and ι gives mappings as follows,natural in A :




One of the conditions of (4.2) says now exactly that π is a "virtual retract" of ι ,as we said:(4.5)




If we moreover have c(π,ι)=idX ,using naturality of c , then π and ι are part of a natural isomorphism C(X,−)≅F ,making X a representing object for F .




(i) ⇒ (iii): Let R be a representing object of F ,together with a natural isomorphism ϕ : C(R,−)⇒F . Define now the element ι′∈FR as follows.

C(R,R)→≅ϕRFR

idR↦ι′:=ϕR(idR)

By the Yoneda lemma,we have that all components of ϕ must be in the following form:




Let now (X,π,ι) be a representative of the class i ,and set A=X in the diagram above. Since we have a bijection,there exists a unique g:R→X such that g∗ι′=ι :





Define now π′=g∗π∈PR :

R→gX⋯⋯π→∙

Consider now the triplet (R,π′,ι′) : first of all,since g∗ι′=ι and π′=g∗π ,we have

[R,π′,ι′]=[X,π,ι]∈⟨P,F⟩.

Moreover,

c(π′,ι′)=c(g∗π,ι′)=c(π,ι′)∘g=idR,

where we used that,by naturality the inverse ϕ−1 ,the following diagram commutes,




as well as (4.2). In summary,the representing object R is part of a triplet (R,π′,ι′) in the class i such that c(π′ι′)=idR .

The proof of (ii)⇔(iii) is completely analogous and dual.

We are now ready to prove the main theorem.

Proof of Theorem 4.4. First of all,the equivalence (i)⇔(ii) was proven in Lemma 4.6.

Second,notice that by definition of C′ ,the inclusion I:C→C′ is fully faithful. Therefore it is an equivalence if and only if it is essentially surjective.

(i)⇒(iii) : Suppose that F is representable. By Lemma 4.6,the representing object X is part of a triple (X,π,ι) representing the class i ,and such that c(π,ι)=idX . Considering now π and ι as morphisms π:X→E and ι:E→X in the category C′ ,we have that ι∘π=c(π,ι)=idX by what we just said,as well as π∘ι=idE by definition of idE in C′ . Therefore E≅X ,making the inclusion I essentially surjective.

(iii) ⇒(i) : Suppose that for some object R of C we have an isomorphism f:E→≅R in C′ . Precomposition with f gives a mapping

C(R,A)→I(−)∘fC′(E,A)=FA

g↦Ig∘f=g∗f

natural in A . This is moreover a bijection,with the following inverse.

C(R,A)=C′(IR,IA)←−∘f−1C′(E,A)=FA

g=Ig←Ig∘f=g∗f

Therefore C(R,−) is naturally isomorphic to F ,i.e. R represents F .


Before we leave this section, let's also define the morphisms of Cauchy points, which will look as follows.




Intuitively, similar to the endomorphisms of a Cauchy point, we want a morphism to be defined only by the existing virtual arrows, without adding any new ones.

Definition 4.7. Let C1=(F1,P1,c1,i1) and C2=(F2,P2,C2,i2) be Cauchy points of C . A morphism of Cauchy points C1→C2 is an element of the pairing

⟨P2,F1⟩=∫C∈CP2(C)×F1(C).

That is,every morphism ∙1⇢∙2 is necessarily in the following form:




Proposition 4.8. A morphisms of Cauchy points C1→C2 is equivalently specified by any of the following.

  • A natural transformation P1⇒P2 ;

  • A natural transformation F2⇒F1 (mind the direction).

Proof. Let [X,p2∈P2,f1∈F1]∈⟨P2,F1⟩ be a morphism of Cauchy points.

∙1⋯→f1X⋯→p2∙2

To construct a natural transformation α:P1⇒P2 we need mappings αA:P1(A)→P2(A) for all A and naturally in A . We construct them as the following "virtual precompositions":




Conversely,given a natural transformation α:P1⇒P2 ,considering a representative (X1,π1,ι1) of i1 we can take the element [X1,α(π1)∈P2(X2),ι1∈F1(X1)]∈⟨P2,F1⟩ .

To show that these assignments are mutually inverse,start first with [X,p2,f1]∈⟨P2,F1⟩ . Forming the natural transformation and the resulting triple we get

[X1,α(π1),ι1]=[X1,c(π1,f1)∗p2,ι1].


Now consider the map c(π1,f1):X1→X : we have that

c(π1,f1)∗ι1=f1,

using (4.2). Therefore,as equivalence classes, [X1,c(π1,f1)∗p2,ι1]=[X,p2,f1] .

Conversely,starting with α:P1⇒P2 ,we have that for all A and p∈PA ,

c(p,ι1)∗αX1(π1)=αA(c(p,ι1)∗π1)=αA(p),

using naturality of α and (4.2).

The construction in terms of natural transformations F2⇒F1 is analogous and dual.

Corollary 4.9. Cauchy points and their morphisms form a category. If we denote it by C¯ ,we have the following commutative diagram of fully faithful embeddings:




Corollary 4.10. A category is Cauchy complete if and only if the inclusion C→C― is an equivalence.

In the next few sections, we will look at some equivalent ways of looking at Cauchy points and Cauchy completion.

4.2 In terms of idempotents


Another way of looking at Cauchy points of unenriched categories is in terms of idempotents and their splittings.

Recall that an idempotent in a category C is an endomorphism e:X→X such that e∘e=e . A splitting of the idempotent e is an object E together with morphisms ι:E→X and π:X→E such that π∘ι=idE ,i.e. forming a section-retraction pair,and such that ι∘π=e :





Notice that, somewhat conversely, every section-retraction pair gives rise to an idempotent, since

(ι∘π)∘(ι∘π)=ι∘(π∘ι)∘π=ι∘id∘π=ι∘π.

One of the most common situations in mathematics where one sees this is in linear algebra, where idempotents are projections onto subspaces E⊆X .

A splitting of an idempotent can be seen as a particular limit or colimit.


Proposition 4.11. Let e:X→X be an idempotent in a category C . The following conditions are equivalent.

(i) e has a splitting (E,π,ι) ;

(ii) The parallel pair

X→ id eX

has an equalizer (E,ι:E→X) ;

(iii) The parallel pair above has a coequalizer (E,π:X→E) .

Moreover, the equalizer and coequalizer above, if they exist, are preserved by every functor.

Proof. For (i)⇒(ii) ,suppose that (E,π,ι) splits e . We have to show that (E,ι) is the equalizer of the pair (e,idX) . Let f:A→X be such that e∘f=id∘f=f . We have to find a unique map u:A→E making the triangle on the left commute:




Take now u=π∘f . We have that

ι∘u=ι∘π∘f=e∘f=f.

To see that u is unique,notice that ι is split monic.

For (ii)⇒(i) ,suppose that (E,ι) is the equalizer of the pair (e,idX) . By idempotency of e ,we have that e∘e=e=id∘e ,so that in the following diagram there is a unique u:X→E making the left triangle commute.




Set now π=u . Commutativity of the triangle gives ι∘π=e . To show that π∘ι=idE ,notice that

ι∘π∘ι=e∘ι=ι=ι∘idE,

and that ι is monic (being an equalizer).

The proofs of (i)⇒(iii) and (iii)⇒(i) are analogous and dual.

Finally,let F:C→D be a functor,and suppose that any (hence all) of the conditions above are satisfied. By functoriality, Fe:FX→FX is an idempotent,split by Fι:FE→FX and Fπ:FX→FE . So by the arguments above, (FE,Fι) is an equalizer and (FE,fπ) is a coequalizer of (Fe,idFX) .

Let's now connect these concepts to Cauchy completion.

Definition 4.12. Let e:X→X be an idempotent of C . The Cauchy point associated to e is constructed as follows.


  • We construct,as in Example 2.4,a functor InvR:C→ Set (for `"right-invariant"`) by

InvR(A):={f:X→A∣f∘e=f}.

On morphisms, it just gives postcomposition of morphisms. (It is a subfunctor of the representable functor C(X,−) .)

  • Dually,we construct a presheaf InvL:Cop → Set by

InvL(A):={p:A→X∣e∘p=p}.

On morphisms, it just gives precomposition of morphisms. (It is a subfunctor of the representable presheaf C(−,X) .)

  • As mapping cA,B:FA×PB→C(A,B) we simply take composition of morphisms;

  • As equivalence class i we take [X,e,e] . (Note that by idempotency, e is both in InvR(X) and in InvL(X) .)

To check conditions (4.2),for every f∈InvR(A) and p∈InvL(A) ,

(4.6)cX,A(e,f)∗e=(f∘e)∘e=f,cA,X(p,e)∗e=e∘(e∘p)=p.

Conversely,given a Cauchy point(F,P,c,i)with i=[X,π,ι] . Recall that,as in (4.3),we can see π and ι as forming a "virtual retract":



"π∘ι=id∙"


It would therefore be tempting to define an idempotent on X by setting e=c(π,ι):X→X . This would indeed be idempotent, since

(4.7)cX,X(π,ι)∘cX,X(π,ι)=cX,X(cX,X(π,ι)∗π,ι)=cX,X(π,ι),

using naturality of c and (4.6). We however need a little care: the resulting construction may not be well defined,since the choice of the object X depends on the chosen representative of i=[X,π,ι] . Indeed, consider the following situation, where we have a "cycle": (Setting π=π′∘g and ι′=g∘ι ,we see that (X,π,ι)∼(Y,π′,ι′)) . We could now take as idempotent either ι∘π′∘g:X→X or g∘ι∘π′:Y→Y . So,in order to have a well defined mapping,we have to define certain equivalence classes of idempotents. We will do even more: we will define a category of idempotents.



(4.8)"π′∘g∘ι=id∙"



Definition 4.13. The Karoubi envelope or idempotent completion of a category C is a category K(C) where

  • Objects are pairs(X,e),where X is an object of C and e:X→X is an idempotent;

  • Morphisms (X,e)→(X′,e′) are morphisms g:X→X′ of C which are bi-invariant,i.e. such that g∘e=e′∘g=g ;

  • The identity (X,e)→(X,e) is given by the morphism e (not by the identity in C );

  • The composition of morphisms is the one of C .

The original category C is embedded into its Karoubi envelope via the fully faithful functor X↦(X,idX) .

In the category K(C) ,two idempotents e:X→X and e′:X′→X′ are isomorphic if and only if there are morphisms g:X→X′ and h:X′→X such that the following diagrams commute.(4.9)




Note that the maps g and h may not be isomorphisms in the category C ,since in the two triangles on the right the idempotents appear instead of the identities of C .

Proposition 4.14. Let e:X→X and e′:X′→X′ be isomorphic idempotents. Then e splits if and only if e′ does,and if so their splittings coincide.

Proof. Consider an isomorphism (g:X→X′,h:X′→X) as defined above,and let (E,π : X→E,ι:E→X) be a splitting of e . Consider now the maps ι′:=g∘ι:E→X′ and π′:=π∘h:X′→E . We have that

ι′∘π′=g∘ι∘π∘h=g∘e∘h=g∘h=e′

and

π′∘ι=π∘h∘g∘ι=π∘e∘ι=π∘ι=idE,

so that (E,π′,ι′) is a splitting of e′ .

Let's now establish the correspondence.

Theorem 4.15. Let C be a category. Definition 4.12 establishes an equivalence of categories K(C)→C― .


Proof. Let’s show that the construction in Definition 4.12 is functorial. Let g:(X,e)→(X′,e′) be a morphism of idempotents,and denote the Cauchy points of(X,e)and (X′,e′) by Φ(X,e)= (InvL,InvR,c,i) and Φ(X′,e′)=(InvL′,InvL′,c′,i′) . By Proposition 4.8,we can equivalently specify a morphism of Cauchy points by a natural transformation InvL⇒InvL′ . We take the one given by postcomposition with g :

InvL(A)→Φ(g)InvL′(A)

(A→pX)↦(A→pX→gX′)

Note indeed that e′∘g∘p=g∘p . (In terms of elements of the pairing,this morphism is specified by [X,g,e]=[X′,e′,g]∈⟨InvL,InvR⟩.) To show that this assignment preserves identities (recall that the identity of(X,e)is e ),notice that

InvL(A)→Φ(e)InvL′(A)

p↦e∘p=p

by the fact that p is left-invariant. Composition,instead,works as usual. This gives a functor Φ:K(C)→C― .

To show that Φ is faithful,let g,h:(X,e)→(X′,e′) be morphisms of idempotents. Suppose that for all A and for all left-invariant morphisms p:A→X,g∘p=h∘p . Then setting A=X and p=e ,we have that g=g∘e=h∘e=h .

To show that Φ is full,let α:InvL⇒InvL′ be a natural transformation. Define g by

InvL(X)→αXInvL′(X)

e↦g:=αX(e).

Notice that,since g is by construction an element of InvL′(X),e′∘g=g . Also,by naturality of α , the following diagram commutes.




Therefore g is a morphism of idempotents. Now again by naturality of α ,for every left-invariant p:A→X ,the following diagram commutes.





In other words, α is in the form Φ(g) for some g:(X,e)→(X′,e′) ,and so Φ is full.

To show that Φ is essentially surjective,let(F,P,c,i)be a Cauchy point,with i=[X,π,ι] . Then e:=c(π,ι):X→X is idempotent,as shown in (4.7). We how have to show that Φ(X,e) is isomorphic to(F,P,c,i). It suffices to prove that the set

(4.10)InvL(A):={p:A→X∣e∘p=p}

is isomorphic to PA for all A ,and naturally in A . First of all,by the Yoneda lemma,natural transformations C(−,X)⇒P are one-to-one with elements of PX . Let’s then take the element π∈PX . For every A the Yoneda lemma gives us a function

C(A,X)→PA

p↦p∗π

Let’s restrict this function to InvL(A) ,and prove that we have a bijection. To prove injectivity, suppose that p,p′∈InvL(A) satisfy p∗π=p′∗π . Now,

p=e∘p=cX,X(π,ι)∘p=c(p∗π,ι)

and the same is true for p′ ,so that we have p=p′ . To prove surjectivity,notice that by (4.2),every p~∈PA satisfies

p~=c(p~,ι)∗π,

so that setting p=c(p~,ι) gives p∗π=p~ . This shows that InvL≅P ,which means that Φ is essentially surjective, and hence an equivalence of categories.

Finally, this correspondence preserves splittings of idempotents.

Proposition 4.16. An idempotent(X,e)splits if and only if its corresponding Cauchy point Φ(X,e) is already in C (in the sense of Theorem 4.4). In that case,the splitting coincides with the representing object.

Proof. By Proposition 4.11, e splits if and only if it admits an equalizer with id : X→X . As we said in Example 2.4,such an equalizer,if it exists,is exactly a representing object for InvL .


In other words, we have a commutative diagram of fully faithful functors as follows.




Corollary 4.17. A category is Cauchy-complete if and only if all its idempotents split.

4.3 In terms of retracts of representables


Another equivalent characterization of the Cauchy completion for unenriched categories, often used in the literature, is as retracts of representables. This is another way of making precise the idea of "virtual retract" that we saw in (4.3):



"π∘ι=id∙"


Proposition 4.18. A Cauchy point of a category C is equivalently specified by a set functor (or presheaf) which is a retract of a representable one.

Proof. Let's prove the assert for functors, the presheaf case is analogous and dual.

First of all,given a Cauchy point(F,P,c,i)with i=[X,π,ι] ,the functor F is a retract of C(X,−) ,as shown in (4.5).

Conversely,suppose that a set functor F is a retract of a representable,meaning that for some object X we have natural transformations ι:F⇒C(X,−) and π:C(X,−)⇒F such that π∘ι=idF . Then the other composition, ι∘π:C(X,−)→C(X,−) ,is idempotent,and since the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful,it corresponds to an idempotent morphism e:X→X . By Theorem 4.15,we have a Cauchy point Φ(X,e) .

To show that this recovers the original functor,i.e. that InvR≅F ,Recall that InvR⊆C(X,−) , and that we already have a retraction ι:F⇒C(X,−),π:C(X,−)⇒F . We need to show that InvR⊆C(X,−) ,just like F ,splits the idempotent natural transformation ι∘π . Now the latter natural transformation acts as follows,

C(X,A)→πAFA→ιAC(X,A)

f↦f∘e,

and so its equalizer with the identity is exactly the set

InvR(A)={f:A→R∣f∘e=f}.

This is true for all objects A ,and so InvR and F are naturally isomorphic.


4.4 In terms of absolute limits


Another important characterization of Cauchy completion is that it is a completion of a category under all those limits and/or colimits which are preserved by any functor.

Definition 4.19. Let D:J→C be a diagram,weighted by W:J→ Set. A W -weighted limit of D is called absolute if it is preserved by every functor F:C→D .

Absolute colimits are defined analogously.

One can interpret absolute limits as cones whose universal property follows directly from the fact that a certain diagram commutes. This tends to look like a "retraction" of some kind (and a "section" of some kind for absolute colimits). Before we make this intuition precise, let's see this at work in an example that should be familiar.

Example 4.20. A splitting (E,π,ι) of an idempotent e:X→X ,as we saw in Proposition 4.11, is both an absolute equalizer and an absolute coequalizer of the parallel pair e ,id :X→X .

Note that,if a map ι:E→X is an equalizer of e and idX if and only if postcomposition with ι makes the natural map

(4.11)C(A,E)→ι∘−InvL(A)

(A→fE)↦(A→fE→ιX)

a natural bijection. Indeed, that's exactly what the universal property of the equalizer says, usually depicted in a diagram as follows.




Now, as we saw in the proof of Proposition 4.11, the reason why the map (4.11) is a bijection is because of the map π :

C(A,E)↔π∘−ι∘−InvL(A)

(A→fE)↦(A→fE→ιX)

(A→gX→πE)↔(A→gX)

Indeed,the two assignments above are mutually inverse thanks to the fact that π∘ι=idE ,i.e. that the following diagram commutes.




In other words, ι is an equalizer because it has a particular retraction π .

Let's now make this "retraction" idea mathematically precise.


Definition 4.21. Consider a diagram D:J→C weighted by W:J→ Set and a weighted cone c with tip T . A eventual retraction of c is an element of the pairing (reversing the arrows of J )

[J,ι,π]∈⟨W−,C(D−,T)⟩=∫J′∈JopWJ′×C(DJ′,T).

such that π∘cJ,ι=idT .

Dually,given weights W:Jop → Set and a weighted co-cone with tip T ,an eventual section is an element of the pairing

[J,π,ι]∈⟨W−,C(T,D−)⟩=∫J′∈JWJ′×C(T,DJ′).

such that cJ,π∘ι=idT .

Let's interpret this graphically (as usual, let's do it for cones, the co-cone case is dual). An eventual retraction [J,ι,π] (or at least a representative of that class) consists explicitly of

  • An object J of J ;

  • A weight ι∈WJ ,i.e. a virtual arrow into J ;

  • A (real) arrow π:DJ→T ,seen as a virtual arrow out of J ,as in Section 3.5.

From these data one can obtain,by functoriality of D and naturality of the cone,a (real) pair of arrows of C :

  • The object DJ of the diagram in C ;

  • The arrow of the cone cJ,ι:T→DJ (note that,by Lemma 3.5,the assignment ι↦cJ,ι can be seen as part of the natural transformation of components WJ→C(T,DJ) ,given by the cone);

  • The arrow π:DJ→T ,this time seen as a real arrow.

∫J′WJ′×C(DJ′,T)→c∗∫J′C(T,DJ′)×C(DJ′,T)




We moreover ask that π∘cJ,ι=idT ,which makes T a retract of DJ .

Now let’s keep in mind that,even if we have a pair of arrows [DJ,cJ,ι:T→DJ,π:DJ→ T]∈∫J′C(T,DJ′)×C(DJ′,T) ,we are taking a coend over J ,not over C ,and so the resulting equivalence class is identifying triplets [J,ι,π] and [J′,ι′,π′] connected as follows,
(4.12)




where the mediating arrows come from J ,i.e. are arrows of the diagram D . We are not quotienting under generic arrows of C .

Note also that eventual retractions are,in a certain sense,closed under precomposition: if π is a retraction of cJ,ι ,for any morphism h:L→J of C ,and for all ι′ in the preimage of ι for the map h∗:WL→WJ ,the composition π∘Dh:DL→T is a retraction of cL,ι′ . Indeed,by the fact that we have a cone,

π∘Dh∘cL,ι′=π∘cJ,h∗ι′=π∘cJ,ι=idT.

Hence the adjective "eventual": at some point in the diagram we have a retraction, and such a retraction can be pulled back along the arrows of the diagram, "all the way towards the limit".

Somewhat dually, by functoriality of weighted colimits, eventual retractions are in a certain sense closed under postcomposition with arrows out of T . Namely,for every object X and arrow f:T→X of C ,we get a function as follows:

⟨W−,C(D−,T)⟩→f∗⟨W−,C(D−,X)⟩

[J,ι,π]↦[J,ι,f∘π]

(T→cJ,ιDJ→πT)↦(T→cJ,ιDJ→πT→fX)

The fact that π is a retraction makes [J,ι,f∘π] satisfy the following condition,

(4.13)(f∘π)∘cJ,ι=f∘(π∘cJ,ι)=f.




Definition 4.22. An eventual retraction [J,ι,π] of c is called a universal retraction if for every object X of C and arrow f:T→X ,any element

[K∈J,w∈WK,DK→gX]∈⟨W−,C(D−,X)⟩

satisfying

g∘cK,w=f





is in the form

[J′,ι∈WJ′,DJ′→π′X]=f∗[J,ι,π]=[J,ι,f∘π].

A universal section of a co-cone is defined dually.

This in particular means that any object DK in the diagram is connected to DJ via arrows of the cone,meaning that the category J is necessarily connected.

Note moreover that a universal retraction, if it exists, must necessarily be unique. Indeed, if [J,ι,π] and [J′,ι′,π′] are universal retractions of c ,the commutative triangle




gives,by universality of [J,ι,π] ,an equality [J′,ι′,π′]=[J,ι,idT∘π]=[J,ι,π] .

Example 4.23. Let e:X→X be an idempotent with splitting (E,π,ι) . We can view this as a diagram of two arrows,with E and ι as limit cone (with unitary weights):




The map π:X→E is now a universal retraction. (Or better,the class [X,ι,π] is,where with a slight abuse we write X and ι instead of the object and element indexing them.) Indeed,let f:E→Y be any function,and consider a function g:X→Y (or,a triplet [X,ι,X→gY] ) making the outer triangle below commute:




In general we cannot assume that g=f∘π necessarily. But it is so up to composing it with arrows of the diagram:

g∘e=g∘ι∘π=f∘π.

Therefore,by the usual equivalence relation,and since e∘ι=ι ,

[X,ι,g]=[X,e∘ι,g]=[X,ι,g∘e]=[X,ι,f∘π]=f∗[X,ι,π].

The general situation is given by the following two statements.

Proposition 4.24. Suppose that a weighted cone admits a universal retraction. Then it is necessarily a limit cone, and it is moreover preserved by all functors (i.e. it is an absolute limit).

The same can be said about co-cones with a universal section.


Proof. Let D:J→C be a diagram weighted by W:J→ Set,let c be a cone with tip T ,and let [J,π,ι] be a (necessarily unique) universal retraction. To show that the cone is a limit,consider another weighted cone,with tip T′ and arrows (dK,w)K∈J,w∈DJ . We have to show that there exist a unique arrow u:T′→T making the respective triangles commute.




Set now u:=π∘dJ,ι:T′→T .

To show that u is well defined,consider an arrow g:J→J′ ,and a triplet (J′,ι′,π′)∼(J,ι,π) such that g∗π′=π and g∗ι=ι′ ,as in (4.12). Chasing the diagram we have,since d is a cone,that

π′∘dJ′,ι′=π′∘Dg∘dJ,ι=π∘dJ,ι.




To show that u makes the desired triangles commute,let K be an object of J . We have to show that for all w∈WK,dK,w=cK,w∘u . Now by universality of [J,ι,π] ,the commutative triangle




gives us an equality [K,w,idDK]=[J,ι,cK,w∘π] . We can carry the equality under the composition mapping (which is well defined) as follows.





Therefore

cK,w∘u=cK,w∘π∘dJ,ι=cK,w,

as desired.

To show that u is unique,notice that if u′:T′→T is such that dJ,ι=cJ,ι∘u′ ,then

u′=π∘cJ,ι∘u′=π∘dJ,ι=u.

Finally, to show that the limit is absolute, notice that we can repeat the same procedure applying a functor to all the arrows: given F:C→D and a limit cone in D with tip T′ and arrows (dK,w)K∈J,w∈DJ ,the unique map u:T′→FT is given by Fπ∘dJ,ι .

Proposition 4.25. Conversely to Proposition 4.24, if a weighted cone is an absolute weighted limit, then it has a universal retraction.

Dually, the same holds for universal weighted colimits and universal sections.

Proof. As usual,we will focus on the limit case. Let D:J→C be a diagram weighted by W:J→ Set,and let c be an absolute limit cone with tip T . Then by definition this limit is preserved by all functors C→D . We now take as functor the Yoneda embedding 10

C→ Yon [C,Set] op 

X↦C(X,−)

Since T is the W -weighted limit of D ,and since we are assuming it is absolute,then Yon(T)= C(T,−) is the weighted colimit of

J→DC→ Yon [C,Set] op 

J↦DJ↦C(DJ,−).

Notice now that limits in [C,Set]op  are colimits in [C,Set] ,and that the latter are computed pointwise,as colimits of sets. We therefore have that for all objects X of C ,

(4.14)C(T,X)≅colimJ∈Jop ⟨WJ,C(DJ,X)⟩.

This weighted colimit can be expressed as a pairing,

colimJ∈Jop ⟨WJ,C(DJ,X)⟩=⟨W−,C(D−,X)⟩

and for X=T it is exactly the one used in Definition 4.21:

C(T,T)≅⟨W−,C(D−,T)⟩=∫J′∈JopWJ′×C(DJ′,T)



10 Technically,the category [C,Set]op  may fail to be locally small if C is not small. So one can,instead,take the category of all small functors C→Set ,i.e. only those that can be expressed as a small limit of representable ones. The resulting category is locally small, see for example [DL07].




Recall now that, since Yon preserves our limit, the arrows of the universal co-cone above an are given by precomposition with the arrows cJ,w:T→DJ of the original limit cone in C :

C(DJ,T)→−∘cJ,wC(T,T)

(DJ→fT)↦(T→cJ,wDJ→fT)

We can now decompose this map as follows,


DJ,T)→∫J′∈JopWJ′×C(DJ′,T)→≅C(T,T)

(DJ→fT)↦[J,w,f]↦(T→cJ,wDJ→fT)


where the first map is the usual inclusion (of the w -th arrow in the tuple) followed by quotienting, and the second map is the isomorphism we considered above. Denote now by [J,π,ι] the element of the pairing corresponding to the identity idT under the isomorphism above. Chasing the diagram,(4.15)




we see that [J,ι,π] is an eventual retraction.

To show that [J,ι,π] is universal,consider an object K of J ,a weight w∈WJ ,and a commutative triangle of C as follows.




We can form a diagram analogous to (4.15) for the weighted colimit (4.14), where the bottom right equality holds now by hypothesis. Now by naturality in X of the isomorphism (4.14), the following diagram commutes.






This is exactly the condition making [J,ι,π] universal.

Let's now connect the theory of absolute limits and colimits to Cauchy completion. It may be helpful first to fix the following terminology.

Definition 4.26. We call a diagram D:J→C weighted by W:J→ Set an absolute diagram if for every functor G:C→D such that the W -weighted limit of G∘D exists in D ,such a limit in D is absolute.

The analogous concept for contravariantly weighted diagrams is defined dually.

In particular, if a weighted diagram has a limit, then it is necessarily a weighted limit. (Note that being absolute is a property of a diagram and its weight.)

Definition 4.27. A (small) set functor F:J→ Set is called an absolute weight if and only if every F -weighted diagram is absolute.

A (small) presheaf P:Jop → Set is called an absolute weight if and only if every P -weighted diagram is absolute.

Theorem 4.28. A diagram D:J→C weighted by W:J→ Set is absolute if and only if the limit set functor in [C,Set]op  of Yon∘D:J→Set is part of a Cauchy point.

We will use first of all the following auxiliary statement, which a way of decomposing limits of composite functors as a two-step process.

Lemma 4.29. Consider functors D:J→C,G:C→D and W:J→ Set. We have that

limJ∈J⁡⟨WJ,GDJ⟩≅limX∈C⁡⟨colimJ∈Jop ⟨WJ,C(DJ,X)⟩,GX⟩,

meaning that one expression exists if and only if the other one does, and if so, they are isomorphic.

Compare for example with sums: given finite sets X and Y ,and functions X→dY→gR ,

∑x∈X⁡g(d(x))=∑y∈Y⁡∑x∈X⁡δd(x),yg(y).




Theorem 4.34. For a Cauchy point, the following conditions are equivalent:

  • It is already in C ;

  • Any (hence all) of the corresponding idempotents has a splitting;

  • The corresponding set functor and/or presheaf is representable;

  • The (absolute) limit or colimit of the identity diagram weighted by the corresponding functor or presheaf exists.

Theorem 4.35. A category C is Cauchy complete if any of the following equivalent conditions hold:

  • Every Cauchy point is already in C ;

  • Every idempotent has a splitting;

  • Every set functor or presheaf which is a retract of a representable one is itself representable;

  • All absolute limits and/or colimits exist.

5 Further topics


Our idea of adding virtual arrows to diagrams can also be used to study more advanced topics, and in those settings, sometimes, it recovers known constructions. We will briefly look at two of them, profunctors and the Day convolution. For more details on them, we refer the reader to the references.

5.1 Profunctors


Definition 5.1. Let C and D be categories. A profunctor Φ:C↛D is a bifunctor

Dop ×C→Φ¯Set.

Alternative names for profunctors appearing in the literature are bimodules, distributors, relators, and others.

As for set functors and presheaves,given objects C of C and D of D ,the set elements of the set Φ¯(D,C) are things that we can postcompose with arrows of C ,and precompose with arrows of D, but not the other way around. It is therefore natural to draw them as "virtual arrows" between D and C as follows:




As we can see,this picture is a generalization of what we did before. Indeed,when either C or D has a single object and a single arrow, we recover the "virtual arrows" of functors and presheaves:


  • A profunctor C↛1 is a functor 1op ×C≅C→ Set,i.e. a set functor on C .

  • A profunctor 1↛D is a functor Cop×1≅Cop→ Set,i.e. a presheaf on C .

Remark 5.2. Mind the possible confusion: in a profunctor C↛D ,i.e. from C to D ,the virtual arrows go from the objects of D to the ones of C . This convention,which seems backwards,is motivated by the special case of functors: in a set functor C→ Set,i.e. from C ,the virtual arrows go to the objects of C . (And for presheaves they go from the objects of C .)

As we did for functors, presheaves, and Cauchy points, it is sometimes helpful to "promote the virtual arrows to real arrows". The resulting concept is well known:

Definition 5.3. The collage of a profunctor Φ:C↛D is the category where

  • The objects are the disjoint union of those of C and those of D ,with their identities;

  • Between two objects of C ,the arrows are those of C ,with their composition;

  • Between two objects of D ,the arrows are those of D ,with their composition;

  • Given objects C of C and D of D ,the arrows D→C are the elements of the set Φ¯(D,C) , with precomposition and postcomposition by arrows of C and D given by functoriality;

  • There are no arrows in the form C→D .

Similarly to what happened the categories C+F,C+P and C′ of Definition 2.1,Definition 2.5 and Definition 4.2,the collage of a profunctor is indeed a category thanks to the functoriality of Φ . In particular, associativity of arrows in the form

C1→cC2→ϕD1→dD2

is guaranteed by bifunctoriality, in the sense of Definition 3.22 and (3.12).

The "virtual arrows" connecting C and D are sometimes called heteromorphisms,to distinguish them from the morphisms (or homomorphisms) within C and within D . (Compare for example with the words homogeneous and heterogeneous.)

Consider now two profunctors as follows.



We can compose them by counting the paths by means of pairings, as in Definition 3.40:



Definition 5.4. Let Φ:C↛D and Ψ:D↛E be profunctors. The composite profunctor Ψ∘Φ:C↛E is given on object,up to isomorphism,by

Ψ∘Φ―(E,C):=⟨Φ¯(−,C),Ψ¯(E,−)⟩=∫D∈DΦ¯(D,C)×Ψ¯(E,D),

and induced on morphisms by the universal property of weighted colimits.

In other words,we are taking as virtual arrows E→C all possible paths via D , as usual, counting only once those paths that only differ by associativity.




With this notion of composition, profunctors form almost a category: it is a bicategory, two-dimensional and weak. (Indeed, the pairing only specifies the composite profunctor up to natural isomorphism.) It can be considered a higher analogue of the category of relations, between categories instead of sets. The identities of this bicategory are given by the hom-functors C(−,−):Cop ×C→ Set, which we can see as profunctors. Indeed, by Yoneda reduction (Proposition 3.14),

∫YC(Y,X)×Φ¯(A,Y)≅Φ¯(A,X).

and a condition on the other side holds analogously.

Remark 5.5. One can define adjunctions in a bicategory similarly to how one does in Cat. This way,a Cauchy point(F,P,c,i)on a category C (Definition 4.1) is exactly a pair of adjoint pro-functors as follows.




Recall indeed that profunctors C→1 are set functors,and profunctors 1→C are presheaves. Moreover the maps

cA,B:PA×FB→C(A,B)


and

i:1→∫XPX×FX

can be seen as the unit i:id1⇒F∘P and counit c:P∘F⇒idC of an adjunction in this profunctor sense. (The conditions (4.2) can be seen as the triangle identities.)

5.2 String diagrams and Day convolution


In a monoidal category (C,⊗,I) we have,besides the usual notion of composition of morphisms,a notion of parallel composition, or tensor product. Because of that, it is often useful to move from ordinary diagrams to string diagrams, where objects are "wires" and morphisms are "boxes". In this document we will orient string diagrams from left to right. A morphism f:X→Y is represented as follows, the composition of two morphisms is represented as follows, and the tensor product as follows.






Now given a functor F:C→ Set,we can represent the elements f∈FX ,i.e. the "virtual arrows to X ",as dashed morphisms from an "extra wire" to X :




We could label the extra wire, in case we have several functors, and we can also not display the extra wire,




if one keeps in mind not to confuse these with morphisms from the monoidal unit, which are usually represented similarly (but in solid lines). As usual,the functorial action of F on morphism is a "virtual postcomposition":




Similarly,and dually,given a presheaf P:Cop → Set we can represent the elements p∈PX , i.e. the "virtual arrows from X " as dashed morphisms from X to an "extra wire", or once again, omitting the wire: The functorial action is "virtual precomposition":







Cauchy completion. Recall from Section 4 that Cauchy points can be seen as particular "extra objects" equipped with "virtual maps" ι and π forming a "virtual retraction". We can draw them for example as follows, with the condition that so that the resulting morphism






is idempotent. (Again we can possibly label the dashed wire in case we are considering more than one point.)

Diagrams of this kind (with slightly different notation) are already widely used in categorical quantum mechanics, where idempotents play a major role, for example, in modeling measurements and decoherence. See for example [CK17, Chapters 6 and 7] and references therein.

Yoneda embedding and Day convolution. Just as we did with non-string diagrams, we can visualize morphisms between presheaves (natural transformations) as virtual morphisms between (labeled) virtual objects:




Similarly,morphisms of functors α:F⇒G are opposite morphisms,once again ( C is embedded in [C,Set]op ).




This way we can represent via string diagrams the entire categories [C,Set]op and [Cop,Set] ,as extensions of the category C .

At this point, a question might arise: Do we have the parallel composition for virtual arrows? The answer is affirmative, and the canonical way to do so is via Day convolution. (For this to work, we need small functors or presheaves.)


Definition 5.6. Let (C,⊗,I) be a monoidal category,and let F,G:C→ Set be (small) set functors. The Day convolution of F and G is the functor F⊗G given on objects up to isomorphism by the following pairing:

(F⊗G)(Z):=⟨C(−⊗−,Z),F−×G−⟩≅∫X,Y∈CC(X⊗Y,Z)×FX×GY

On morphisms it is induced by the universal property.

Dually,given (small) presheaves P and Q ,the Day convolution P⊗Q is the presheaf defined on objects by the following pairing:

(P⊗Q)(X):=⟨P−×Q−,C(Z,−⊗−)⟩≅∫Y,Z∈CPY×QZ×C(X,Y⊗Z)

Let's now interpret this. As usual, let's focus on set functors. The idea is that we want to define a product F⊗G . In string diagrams,it should look like the parallel composition of the following virtual objects:




Now F⊗G is a set functor. What are its elements? Given an object Z ,what are the elements of the set (F⊗G)(X) ? Or,equivalently (by the Yoneda lemma),what are the natural transformations Yon(Z)⇒F⊗G ,i.e. the morphisms F⊗G→Yon(Z) of [C,Set]op  ?




The pairing in Definition 5.6 has,as elements,equivalence classes of tuples(X,Y,h,f,g)with h:X⊗Y→Z,f∈FX and g∈GY ,




which we can imagine arranged as follows:





Moreover,the equivalence relation identifies tuples that differ by any morphisms a:X→X′ and b:Y→Y′ as follows:




Indeed,by the Yoneda lemma,we can view f and g as morphisms of [C,Set]small op  ,and both sides above give rise to the following composition, which is now well defined.




In particular,in line with everything we did so far,the only elements of (F⊗G)(Z) are the ones which one can obtain purely via the elements of F ,the elements of G ,and the morphisms of C .

With these definitions,one can prove that the categories [C,Set]small op  and [C,Set]small op  are monoidal categories,with the unit given by Yon(I) ,where I is the unit of C . Moreover,the Yoneda embedding is not just fully faithful, but also strong monoidal:

Proposition 5.7. Let (C,⊗,I) be a monoidal category,and assume [C,Set]small op  equipped with the Day convolution tensor product. The Yoneda embedding C↪[C,Set]small op  is a strong monoidal functor. The same thing can be said for presheaves.

Because of this, the parallel composition of virtual arrows extends faithfully the one of ordinary arrows. Note moreover that,since C is embedded,we can also form diagrams,for example,as follows i.e. Yon(X)⊗Yon(A)→Yon(g)⊗pYon(Y)⊗P




(recalling that by the Yoneda lemma, p is an element of PX or,equivalently,a natural transformation Yon(X)⇒P) ,or even as follows.



i.e. Yon(X)→Yon(h)Yon(Y)⊗Yon(A)→id⊗pYon(Y)⊗P



Sketch of proof. As usual, let's focus on the functor case. The condition on the unit holds by definition. For products, using Yoneda reduction (Proposition 3.14),

(Yon(A)⊗Yon(B))(Z)≅∫X,Y∈CC(X⊗Y,Z)×C(A,X)×C(B,Y)

≅C(A⊗B,Z)

=Yon(A⊗B)(Z).

The associativity and unitality conditions hold by the universal property.

5.3 Additional material


Here are some references where one can learn more about the material presented here.

  • For more ideas on these `"virtual arrows"`, see [Ell15].

  • For Kan extensions, we recommend Chapter 6 of [Rie16].

  • For ends and coends, as well as Day convolution, see [Lor21].

  • For Cauchy completion, idempotent splitting and absolute limits, [Par71] and [BD86].

  • For general notions of limits and weighted limits, [Par73], [Bor94], [Kel82], and [Par15].

  • For profunctors, see again [Lor21, Chapter 5], and [Bé73] (in French).
